screening_results.reason: fMRI study of face identity and eye-gaze perception — clearly social-related processing (social communication/perception of others), satisfying I1. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone), so include for full-text review to verify I2.

fMRI study measuring amygdala responses to racial ingroup vs outgroup faces, which is a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participants identified as White or Black (healthy adults implied), but age range not reported; include for full-text to confirm I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining gaze direction effects on face processing—a social perception/communication task—so I1 is satisfied. Participant health status and ages (18–65) are not reported in the abstract, so inclusion cannot be fully confirmed without full text; therefore include for full-text review.

Functional MRI was used while healthy volunteers performed social tasks (empathy and forgivability judgments), directly addressing social-related processing. Although participant ages are not specified, the sample of 'ten volunteers' is consistent with adult healthy participants; include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

Event-related fMRI recorded while human subjects performed social judgments (trustworthiness of faces), clearly a social processing task. Participants are described as subjects (healthy adults implied) within typical adult age range. This meets inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

Abstract describes simultaneous fMRI during a social interaction (a deception game between pairs), satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages 18–65, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.

The study uses fMRI during attributional decision tasks probing self-related social cognition (self-responsibility, self-serving bias) and reports results in normal/healthy subjects. Thus it meets I1 and I2.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI measuring neural responses to social/moral judgments of faces (meets I1). It does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status in abstract, so full text is needed to confirm I2; therefore include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in normal (healthy) subjects performing a social-related task (watching movie clips of social interactions), matching the review objective. No exclusion criteria apply. fMRI study examining neural responses to mutual vs. averted gaze—a social perception/communication task—reporting STS and FFG activations. Participants are described as 'subjects' with no clinical populations indicated, consistent with healthy adult sampling. Meets criteria for an fMRI social-task study and inclusion of healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social interactions (cooperation vs competition) involving monitoring others’ actions and social cognition, satisfying I1. Participants are human and described as 'individuals' (healthy adult sample implied), meeting I2. No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study with healthy volunteers performing a social-related task (evaluative judgments of guilt and embarrassment involving Theory of Mind/social cognition). Abstract reports 19 healthy participants, meeting inclusion requirements. Age range not specified in abstract — included for full-text review to confirm ages.

This is a narrative review of MRI findings in adolescent brain maturation, not a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review/review article). The abstract does not report fMRI results in healthy adult participants.

The abstract describes two fMRI experiments on understanding intentions in social interactions—a social cognition task relevant to the review. While participant ages are not specified, the study appears to involve healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

Event-related fMRI study of self-face recognition (perception/understanding of self), using healthy normal subjects—meets I1. Abstract indicates ten right-handed normal subjects but does not report ages, so I2 (age 18–65) cannot be confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review to verify age eligibility.

fMRI study where participants performed impression formation about other people, a clear social-cognitive task (Perception and Understanding of Others). Event-related fMRI in healthy participants examined processing of emotional (angry) voice prosody—a social communication task assessing perception/understanding of others. Fits social-related processing in adults. Abstract indicates healthy subjects; no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind and empathy) in healthy human volunteers; meets I1. Participants described as healthy volunteers, but age range (18–65) not reported in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation of I2.

fMRI study examining recognition of visual feedback as self- versus other-generated (perception/understanding of self/others), which is a social-related construct. fMRI study scanning participants during a face-perception/one-back task where affective person knowledge (social cognition) is spontaneously retrieved—meets social-related processing (I1). This fMRI study measured neural responses to faces and facial expressions (social perception of others), meeting I1. The abstract does not report participant ages or explicit healthy status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.

The study used functional MRI to measure brain activity during kinship-related social scenarios evoking affiliative emotion, meeting I1 (social-related fMRI task). The abstract describes human participants with no indication of clinical populations, implying healthy adults, satisfying I2. No exclusion criteria apply.

Study used fMRI while mothers listened to infant cries probing attachment/affiliation-related social processing, meeting I1. Participants are adult mothers with no clinical groups mentioned, consistent with healthy adults (I2). Age ranges not explicit, so some uncertainty remains; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study investigating empathy/perspective taking (social cognition) in healthy adult participants (n=18). Task involves self/other perspective taking during pain perception, meeting social-processing construct; participants are healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text extraction and analysis.

Abstract reports fMRI during social-cognition tasks in neurologically normal participants, meeting the review objective. Age range (18–65) is not specified, so full-text review is needed to confirm I2.

fMRI study involving human participants processing emotional facial expressions (social communication/perception of others), meeting I1. Sample consists of adolescents rather than adults (not within 18–65), and the fMRI task (Monetary Incentive Delay) is a monetary reward task rather than an explicitly social-related task. Therefore the study does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2 based on the abstract.

Abstract reports an fMRI study probing social-cognitive processes (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems) while participants performed action observation tasks under cognitive load, indicating a social-related task. Participants are human (presumably healthy adults) and no review/meta-analysis. Therefore it meets I1 and I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of visual perspective selection, a social-cognition task (perspective taking). Although participant health/ages are not explicitly stated, this is a typical healthy adult cognitive neuroscience sample; include for full-text verification of demographics.

This fMRI study measured BOLD responses during action observation and execution after sensorimotor training pairing shapes with hand actions, addressing mirror responses relevant to perception/understanding of others (social processing). Human participants are reported; likely healthy adults. Satisfies criteria I1 and I2.

Abstract reports a combined fMRI and eye-tracking study of social cognition (interaction vs observation) in human participants, satisfying I1. No clinical groups or ages are specified but participants appear to be healthy adults and no disorders are mentioned, so I2 is likely met; include for full-text to confirm demographics.

Abstract reports an fMRI study manipulating sociality during a working memory (n-back) task in humans, satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and ages.

The study used fMRI to measure neural responses while healthy adult participants viewed others in pain (a social perception/understanding of others task). Participants were healthy adults (likely 18–65). This directly meets the review objective and inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of person memory and recognition (familiar, famous, novel faces), which qualifies as social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). This fMRI study investigates perception of others' gender from facial cues, a social-perception task (meets I1). The abstract mentions participants but does not specify ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm I2 (healthy adults 18–65).

fMRI study explicitly examines neural responses during interpersonal resource conflicts (a social task). The abstract reports fMRI while participants performed tasks manipulating abstract vs. concrete mindsets, but it does not clearly state that tasks involved social-related processing nor report participant ages/health. Study used fMRI while participants judged attractiveness of other people (a social-related task — perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not report participant ages or clinical status, so inclusion for full-text review is needed to confirm age 18–65 and health status.

Study used task-based fMRI to examine neural responses to social inclusion/exclusion (social processing) in human participants; meets age/group criterion implied (healthy adult participants). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text screening.

Abstract reports two fMRI experiments in which participants made mental-state (social-cognitive) judgments about individuals and groups, meeting I1. Participant ages/health status are not specified, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI to measure neural responses to real-world romantic interest/rejection (a social task involving perception and understanding of others) in participants who underwent scanning. fMRI study investigating communicative intentions and brain systems (mentalizing and mirror neuron) during social interaction tasks; likely healthy adult participants typical for such neuroimaging work. fMRI study in healthy adults (mean age 24) using a social task (hand-holding with friend vs stranger vs alone) that probes social regulation of threat-related neural responses. Meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult participants). No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI was used while participants processed different types of laughter and attended to social information, addressing social communication/perception (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (I2 unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of communicative (social) gestures during observation and imitation, involving human participants (n=20). Directly addresses social communication (I1). Abstract reports training-related changes in neural activation and connectivity associated with altruistic behavior in healthy adults, indicating functional neuroimaging of social processing. fMRI study examining social-related processing (responses to outcomes for self, friend, antagonist) in healthy participants (N=31). fMRI was used while participants encoded and later propagated social messages, addressing social cognition/communication (mentalizing/reward systems). fMRI study of social-related processing (recognition of others' action 'vitality forms') satisfies I1. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (18–65), so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; per instructions, include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind (social cognition) tasks comparing emotions, beliefs, and pain in 46 volunteers; involves healthy participants and social-related processing, meeting I1 and I2.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social-evaluative processing (self-conscious emotion) with neural responses reported (MPFC, striatum), addressing social-related processing. This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21 males) who performed a social-related task (rating naturalness of dyadic nonverbal interactions), addressing perception/understanding of others. Abstract reports an fMRI study of impression formation (social cognition) in human participants; no indication of clinical populations. Fits social-related task with healthy adult participants; meets inclusion criteria for full review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using perception of biological motion (a social perception task) and includes adult participants; thus it meets I1 (fMRI during a social-related task) and I2 (includes healthy adults aged 18–65). No exclusion criteria apply.

This study used fMRI while healthy participants performed social-related tasks (eye-gaze detection, self-propelling motion, implicit mental-inference role-playing), addressing social perception and mentalizing. Participants are described as healthy (adult) subjects. No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI was conducted during a third-party punishment task probing attribution of intentions and moral responsibility—social cognition. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Thus it meets both I1 and I2.

fMRI was used while participants viewed socio-cognitive (social-awareness campaign) videos; study compares drivers with frequent offenses and safe drivers (presumably healthy adult participants). The task probes social cognition (STS reactivity). Satisfies inclusion criteria I1 and I2.
Abstract explicitly identifies the paper as a review. Although it discusses fMRI findings, it is a review article rather than a primary fMRI study, so exclusion criterion E1 applies.

This fMRI study used a faces vs objects viewing paradigm—face perception is a social-related process (Perception/Understanding of Others), meeting I1. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI while participants evaluated personal attributes about themselves (a social cognition/self-processing task), satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review.

Study investigates birdsong and reports fMRI work in songbirds (non-human). It does not involve human participants (ages 18–65) performing social-related tasks, so it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

Abstract describes brain responses during evaluation of face approachability (a social processing task) but does not specify that functional MRI was used nor participant characteristics (healthy adults, ages 18–65). Abstract reports two independent fMRI experiments using a social-empathy visuo-tactile task assessing emotional egocentricity bias in human participants; it also includes behavioral and TMS experiments. Abstract reports an event-related fMRI paradigm using dynamic social vs nonsocial gestures, addressing social processing (meets I1). Abstract reports fMRI in human participants performing collaborative and competitive tasks (social contexts) and examines brain mechanisms of social motivation; likely healthy adult participants. This meets fMRI social-task criterion and includes healthy adults. Not a review.

Abstract reports a social-judgment task and accompanying neural activation in somatosensory, amygdala, hippocampus and prefrontal regions, implying functional neuroimaging in healthy adults. Abstract reports fMRI responses to moral sentiments (guilt) and study of proneness to social/moral emotions in healthy individuals, indicating an fMRI social-related task (I1). Simultaneous fMRI was used while participants engaged in live verbal interaction (social communication), fulfilling social-related task requirement. Participants were pairs of adult female friends (healthy adults), satisfying the healthy adult group criterion. Not a review or meta-analysis.

The study used fMRI while 44 healthy participants made social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) of voices, directly addressing social-related processing (I1). No exclusion criteria apply.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social communication/empathy using dynamic video clips and analyzes BOLD responses—meeting I1. This is a task-based fMRI study examining social cognitive processes (empathy, Theory of Mind, self-other differentiation), satisfying I1. Study used fMRI while participants engaged in one-shot prisoner's dilemma decisions examining neural correlates of social cognition (meets I1). Abstract is an overview/narrative that mentions early fMRI studies of social emotions but does not report original methods or participant details (e.g., whether healthy adults aged 18–65 were scanned). Abstract reports an fMRI study comparing neural responses to familiar vs unfamiliar faces (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others). Abstract examines social decision-making (ultimatum game) and neural networks, but does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or report participant ages (18–65). Abstract reports functional MRI during live reciprocal imitation of hand gestures, a social cognitive task. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

This fMRI study measured brain responses while healthy adult participants received interpersonal manual touch from other people—an inherently social stimulus involving perception/processing of others. Abstract reports examination of neural substrates of social cognition and face processing in a group of healthy young adults, meeting criterion I2. Abstract reports human fMRI decoding of social familiarity (friends vs acquaintances), meeting I1. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI task (social closeness with photos of friends vs unknown people) assessing social processing and relates neural activity to social network measures in healthy adults — meets criteria for task-based fMRI in social domain and healthy adult participants. fMRI study of social self/other/reflected evaluations (social processing) and includes a healthy young adult group (ages 22–31) within 18–65. Abstract describes task-based fMRI and healthy participants, meeting both inclusion criteria.

The study reports an fMRI experiment examining neural responses to a social situation (bystander effect) while participants witness an emergency, satisfying I1. Participants are non-human (dogs, N=12). Meta-analysis requires fMRI studies in healthy adult human participants (age 18–65) performing social-related tasks. The abstract clearly indicates a canine sample, so it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

fMRI study where 20 typical (healthy) participants performed a social attribution task (self/other/situation), directly addressing social cognition. Meets I1 (task during fMRI) and I2 (healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment where participants performed a social attribution task (attributing awareness to another), meeting social-processing fMRI criterion. Participants are described as subjects (healthy adults implied); include for full-text if age details needed.

fMRI study of social behavior (Cyberball and modified Dictator Game) addressing social exclusion/punishment/forgiveness — meets social-related task criterion. fMRI was used during a social-related task (anticipatory interpersonal touch comparing human vs fake hand), meeting I1. The abstract implies healthy human participants but does not report ages explicitly; therefore include for full-text review to confirm I2 (age 18–65). No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract reports an fMRI study where participants performed tasks involving self- and other-referential recollection (social cognition regarding self and others). fMRI measured responses to faces (natural vs bluish) which is social communication/perception (facial cues), satisfying I1. Abstract reports 25 subjects but does not state ages or health status, so I2 is unclear; include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants viewed and processed realistic social interaction videos (empathic/social processing), and the sample comprised healthy young adult males within the adult age range. Thus it meets both I1 and I2.

fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others (third-person social interaction), satisfying I1. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review.

fMRI study using an ultimatum game examines social fairness processing (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (I2 unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample.

fMRI was conducted while healthy volunteers performed a social interaction/game with various agents, addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not report participant ages; full text needed to confirm age 18–65, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants formed impressions of others (social evaluation/perception of others), meeting the social-related task requirement and participant criteria. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed an implicit false-belief (theory-of-mind) task — a social cognition paradigm (meets I1). This fMRI study investigates cross-modal recognition of other individuals (social perception/understanding of others) using a voice-face priming task in human participants, satisfying I1. Abstract reports an fMRI study measuring neural responses to biological vs scrambled motion—clearly a social-perception task (I1). The sample is described as ‘humans’ but health status and ages (18–65) are not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants (N=50, young volunteers) labeled briefly presented emotional facial expressions—a social perception/understanding task. This directly meets the review objective and both inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment probing social communication (perceived friend vs computer), examining neural encoding and interregional coupling related to social context. Abstract reports model-driven functional MRI of social tie formation during an economic (public goods) interaction, addressing social processing. The abstract does not specify participant age/health status, so full-text is needed to confirm I2. Include for full-text screening.

Abstract reports neural measurements during social communicative interactions but does not specify fMRI or participant ages/health. Mouse resting-state fMRI study; not conducted in human adults nor involving a social-related task. Does not meet inclusion criteria I1 (social task in humans) or I2 (healthy human participants 18–65).

The abstract describes an fMRI study of joint attention (a social cognitive task), satisfying I1. Participant health status and ages are not reported in the abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports dyadic fMRI during eye contact and derives neural bases for reciprocal social interaction, indicating a social-related task using fMRI (meets I1). Abstract reports an fMRI study measuring neural responses while participants judged social interactions (a social-related perceptual task), meeting I1. This is an fMRI study of perception of emotions in dynamic crowds (social processing), satisfying I1. The study used fMRI during a game-theoretic deception task, which is a social-related processing paradigm (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study examining attributions about social situations (social cognition). Abstract indicates human participants performing social-related tasks and reports neural activation; likely healthy adult sample. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study examining neural regulation of behavioral mimicry in response to social cues (emotional expression and group membership), which fits social processing constructs; abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health but likely healthy adults. Empirical fMRI study of gaze following (social perception/understanding of others) in human participants. Participants are described as healthy adults; task probes social attention and interaction. No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study where participants judged and conceptualized actions; task taps perception/understanding of others and mental-state reasoning, fitting social-related processing (I1). fMRI study using social-emotional stimuli (angry and happy faces) during task performance with healthy adult subjects (N=30). This meets the review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults; abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of 164 healthy adult participants (age range fits 18–65) performing an interactive mentalizing task (Prisoner’s Dilemma), addressing social cognition/attachment. Thus meets I1 (social-related task during fMRI) and I2 (healthy adult sample). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an fMRI study probing processing of social reputation (social-related task), satisfying I1. fMRI study of empathy (social processing: perception/understanding of others) in a minimal-group task with 30 healthy adult participants (18–65). It reports task-based BOLD activation during social-related stimuli and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants watched videos of a violent social interaction—this is a social perception/understanding task, satisfying I1. The abstract does not report participants' health status or ages, so I2 is unclear; include for full-text review to confirm.

fMRI study explicitly investigates self-referential and social stimulus processing in humans, meeting I1. Participant health status and ages (18–65) are not specified in the abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a social-related facial emotion (disgust) perception task examining racial prejudice and neural responses; meets social processing domain. Abstract does not state ages but implies adult healthy participants; include for full-text to confirm demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study using a valence classification task on agency and communion (social cognition)—meets I1. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages (18–65) so inclusion for full-text review is needed to confirm I2.

fMRI study examining speech acts (social communication) with participants performing communicative tasks during scanning, meeting social-related task criterion. fMRI study examining processing of social versus nonsocial gestures (a social-related task). Abstract reports correlations with personality traits and does not indicate clinical populations; implies healthy adult participants. Study is empirical (not a review). Meets I1 and I2.

Whole-brain fMRI was conducted while participants viewed faces of other group members, examining social cognition and valuation related to others' popularity (social perception/understanding of others). No clinical populations are mentioned, implying healthy adult participants. Thus it meets I1 and I2.

fMRI study with 26 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (empathy-evoking film clips with contextual and musical manipulations). Investigates social cognition neural mechanisms; not a review. Abstract provides clear evidence meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining neural processing of speech in an interactive (social) context, addressing mentalizing/social cognition. Participant health/age not explicitly stated, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (18–65) sample.

fMRI study using MVPA of social cognition to identify neural dimensions of mental state representation — meets I1. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so full-text needed to confirm I2.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (N=26) performed a social task (learning about others' generosity) with neural prediction-error analyses; meets the review focus on social processing in healthy adults. Abstract not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract reports fMRI during live eye-contact social interaction (a social-related task), satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; per instructions, include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

Abstract reports real-time fMRI (rt-fMRI) combined with EEG to train social communication skills and analyzes activations in the right pSTS, indicating an fMRI study of social-related processing. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

fMRI study where participants performed guilt-related tasks (imagined and recollected), probing affective and social-cognition regions — meets I1. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status, so I2 cannot be fully confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review.
Study used macaque (non-human) participants in fMRI; does not include human adults. Therefore it fails the review’s inclusion criteria requiring human healthy adults (I1/I2).

This is an fMRI study of affective theory of mind (social processing) in healthy adult participants (21 analyzed). It directly assesses perception/understanding of others using a social task and is not a review. Criteria I1 and I2 are met.

fMRI study investigating emotional and cognitive empathy during social feedback—clearly a social-related task. Sample comprises 20 healthy adult participants. Thus meets I1 (functional MRI during a social task) and I2 (healthy adults). No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract reports block-design fMRI measuring neural responses to perception of facial expressions (a social communication/perception task). It does not specify participant age/health status in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm I2.
Although an fMRI study of social processing, the sample comprises children and adolescents only; no healthy adult (18–65) group is reported, so it fails inclusion criterion I2.

fMRI study of social evaluation using videos in a sample of 37 healthy participants; directly investigates neural processing of social-related stimuli (social evaluation), meeting the review objective. Age not specified in abstract but participants are described as healthy adults. Include for full-text review to confirm exact ages if needed.

fMRI was used while participants performed a trustworthiness ratings task (a social cognition task), meeting I1. Abstract implies human participants but does not specify ages or health status, so full text is needed to confirm I2.

fMRI experiment investigating person perception and mentalising (social cognition) during tasks pairing bodies/names with trait statements; implies healthy adult participants in an experimental fMRI study. Meets criteria for a social-related fMRI task and includes healthy participants.

Participants are domestic dogs (non-human). Meta-analysis requires fMRI studies in healthy human adults aged 18–65. Abstract clearly reports animal participants, so inclusion criteria I1 and I2 are not met.

Abstract describes an essay/perspective arguing for cross-species integration in social neuroscience rather than reporting original human fMRI data. It is a review-type article, not a primary fMRI study of healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social processing — meets I1. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy adult status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports fMRI during a visually based social judgment task (evaluating social dominance in faces) in a sample of 23 healthy adults, matching the review’s focus on social-related processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI was used while participants attended to the social meaning of symbolic artifacts, engaging social cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ), satisfying I1. The abstract does not explicitly report participant ages or explicitly state ‘healthy adults,’ so I2 is unclear; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a social interaction (virtual ball-toss) task that probes social reward processing, meeting I1. Participant sample (n=38) is given but health status and ages (18–65) are not specified; therefore include for full-text review to confirm I2.

Task-based fMRI examined self-referential processing, a social-cognitive construct relevant to the review (meets I1). The study includes a healthy control group, but the abstract does not report participant ages, so I2 (age 18–65) cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify age eligibility.

fMRI was used during a social cognitive emotion-regulation task involving a psychotherapist (social regulation) in adult participants; measures include attachment and social functioning. No exclusion criteria met. Meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (adult healthy participant group implied).

The study used fMRI during a social interaction/aggression task (retaliation to provocation), meeting the social-processing task requirement. It reports healthy volunteers as participants, consistent with inclusion of healthy adults; age range not stated in abstract, so full-text review needed to confirm ages. No exclusion criteria apply.

Abstract reports neural correlates of mentalizing (a social-cognitive process) and brain structure differences linked to OXTR polymorphism, implying fMRI investigation of social-related processing in adults. No indication the paper is a review. Therefore it appears to meet criteria I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult participants).

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a charitable-giving task probing empathy, perspective taking, and attention shifts (clearly social-related processing). Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract, so full text is needed to confirm I2 (18–65 healthy adults). Include for full-text review to verify sample demographics.

Abstract describes methodological analysis of brain network community structure during rest and task states, with no mention of social-related tasks or social processing. Inclusion criterion I1 (social-related fMRI task) is not met.

Abstract reports neural-level analyses and dynamic causal modeling of empathy and mentalizing in naturalistic social tasks, implying functional neuroimaging. However, it does not explicitly state 'fMRI' or report participant ages. Include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and that participants are healthy adults (18–65).
Participants are preadolescent children (age ~11), not adults. The study does not meet the required participant age range (18–65) specified in inclusion criterion I2, so it must be excluded.

Abstract reports an fMRI study probing theory-of-mind/social cognition during cooperative vs. competitive interactions (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state ‘healthy’ adults, so I2 cannot be fully confirmed from the abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social cognition task (inferring others' emotions and learning from feedback), which meets I1. The abstract does not specify participant age/health, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

Abstract describes a genetic/environmental study of response inhibition in adolescents, with no mention of fMRI or social-processing tasks; participants are adolescents (not age 18–65). Does not meet the review’s fMRI-in-healthy-adults social processing criteria.
Participants are children (mean age 10.2 years), not adults. The review requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 18–65 (I2), so this study does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining impression updating of other people (social perception/understanding), satisfying I1. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review.

This is an fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition) involving 19 healthy subjects scanned during a social-related task (REMICS). It meets I1 (social fMRI task) and I2 (healthy participant group). Age range not specified but abstract indicates healthy adults; include for full-text verification.

Study sample consists of adolescents, not adults. Meta-analysis requires healthy adults aged 18–65 (I2). Although an fMRI social-task was used (I1), the participant age range falls outside the inclusion criterion, so exclude based on age mismatch.

Randomized longitudinal fMRI study using the Ultimatum Game, a social decision-making task assessing cooperation/affiliation. Participants underwent mindfulness vs control training, implying healthy adult sample. Thus it meets fMRI social-processing (I1) and includes healthy adult participants (I2).

Participants are children in middle childhood (≈7–13 years), not adults. Review requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 18–65 (I2). Although the study uses fMRI and a social task (I1 satisfied), the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study in human subjects including a theory-of-mind (social attribution) task, indicating social processing. Subjects appear to be healthy adults scanned with fMRI. Study is original research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a social exclusion/performance task (meets I1). The sample health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion regarding healthy adults (I2) cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; full-text review is warranted.

Abstract appears to be a narrative review of ecstatic and related seizures mentioning fMRI studies but provides no details of an fMRI social-related task or inclusion of healthy adult participants (18–65). Insufficient information to determine whether I1/I2 are met — include for full-text review.

This fMRI study uses naturalistic movie viewing to probe processing of social interactions (perception/understanding of others), satisfying I1. The abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly confirm they are healthy adults, so include for full-text review to verify I2.

This is an fMRI study in twenty (presumably healthy) adult participants performing a social-emotional task (watching actors in angry vs. joyful situations), examining neural responses and connectivity related to social cognition. It directly meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult group). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion in full review.

The study used fMRI during self-reference and reference-to-others tasks, which are social-cognitive processes (Perception/Understanding of Self and Others), satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (18–65), so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; therefore include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

fMRI experiments were conducted while participants played social economic games (Prisoner's Dilemma, Ultimatum Game), addressing social processing. Participant health status and ages (18–65) are not specified in the abstract; include for full-text confirmation.
fMRI study in healthy adults (N=25) using attachment-related stimuli assessing social cognition/mentalizing. Meets criteria for a social-related fMRI task and healthy participant group.

Abstract reports neural tracking in frontal regions during cooperative/competitive tasks, indicating task-based neuroimaging of social processing in human participants. While ages/health status are not explicitly stated, the study investigates typical self/other processing in humans and should be included for full-text review to confirm fMRI methods and participant demographics.

fMRI study of social cooperation (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) clearly addresses social processing and used functional MRI, satisfying I1. Abstract reports 25 female participants but does not specify ages or explicitly state they are healthy, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review.

The study reports fMRI data collected while healthy adults performed mental-state judgments about naturalistic social interactions (a social cognition task), satisfying I1 and I2. It is an original empirical study, not a review.
Abstract explicitly states this is a review article ('In this review'), not an original fMRI study. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses (E1).

Task-based fMRI of reappraisal of angry faces assesses social perception/understanding of others (social processing). Abstract implies healthy participants and uses task fMRI; age not specified, so include for full-text to confirm demographics.
Study uses awake canine (dog) participants, not human adults; therefore it does not meet the human participant inclusion criterion (I2).

The study used fMRI while participants performed a prosocial learning task (social processing) and examines empathy and neural mechanisms of learning for others. The sample is described as human participants (typical healthy adult sample implied). Thus it meets I1 (social fMRI task) and I2 (healthy human participants).

fMRI study where participants performed mentalizing and empathy/prosocial tasks, satisfying social-related task criterion (I1). Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adult sample, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

The abstract describes an fMRI study of social cognition (thinking about kin and friends), meeting I1. Participant health/age (18–65) is not specified in the abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI during face emotional processing, which is a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to determine I2.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a socially competitive learning task (social feedback/interaction). Addresses social-related processing (competition, social-referencing) during task; meets inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

Abstract reports neuroimaging of social language exposure and re-transmission and links neural activity in mentalizing regions to social language use. However it does not explicitly state that the imaging modality was fMRI nor report participant ages/health. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and healthy adult sample.

The abstract explicitly states this is a review ('In this review') summarizing neuroimaging studies of brain development. It is a review article rather than an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults, meeting exclusion criterion E1.

Abstract mentions neural correlates of face recognition and oxytocin receptor variation but does not explicitly state that functional MRI was conducted during a social-related task or specify participant ages/health. Insufficient information to confirm I1/I2; include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants completed a social cognitive task (emotion recognition with gaze manipulation), meeting I1. The study includes healthy younger adults (mean 20.65) and older adults; age reporting is slightly ambiguous (younger range includes 17), so include for full-text to confirm I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of empathy for pain and prosocial behavior, which is a social-related task (satisfies I1). The abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, so full text is needed to confirm I2; therefore include for full-text review.

Primary fMRI study in healthy human participants examining attribution of emotions to humans and animals. Tasks included passive observation and explicit judgments of emotional descriptors, which assess social cognition/perception of others. No indication of clinical groups or that this is a review. Meets criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

The study used EEG to measure mu rhythm, not functional MRI; therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (requires fMRI). The abstract does describe healthy adult participants, but modality mismatch is decisive. No exclusion criteria (E1) apply.

The study used fMRI while healthy volunteers viewed emotional facial expressions (social-related processing). The abstract reports 40 healthy participants, satisfying the healthy group requirement; ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age range. Meets I1 and I2.
The article is itself a coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies (30 articles). This meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review or meta-analysis).

Study used non-human primates (monkeys) with fMRI and microstimulation; no human participants aged 18–65 are included. Thus it fails the review's requirement for human healthy adult participants and does not meet inclusion criteria I1/I2.
This record is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original fMRI study), which meets exclusion criterion E1.

fMRI was used while participants attended to social information in faces (emotional valence, age), addressing social perception/understanding of others. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so full-text review is needed to confirm criterion I2. Include for full-text screening.

fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (discriminating social interactions from neutral movements), and the sample includes healthy adults aged 20–41 (within 18–65). Thus it meets I1 and I2; no exclusion criteria apply.
This is an animal (rat) resting-state fMRI study; participants are not human adults and no social-related task was performed. It does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

Participants are adolescents (not adults). Although the study uses fMRI with a social-evaluation task (meets I1), it does not include healthy adults aged 18–65, so it fails inclusion criterion I2. No exclusion criteria (e.g., reviews) apply.

Abstract discusses neural mechanisms of information sharing and social consequences, which is relevant to social processing, but it does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or report participant ages/health. Insufficient detail to confirm criteria from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI while participants retrieved biographical/person knowledge about others, a social-cognition task (meets I1). The abstract reports 50 participants across two studies, implying healthy adult samples; exact ages not specified but likely within 18–65, so include for full-text confirmation (I2). No exclusion criteria apply.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment where participants performed mentalising/theory-of-mind tasks (social cognition), satisfying I1. The health status and ages (18–65) of participants are not specified in the abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify I2.

Participants were adolescent girls (minors), not adults 18–65, so the study does not meet inclusion criterion I2 (healthy adults). The abstract does not indicate any adult sample. No listed exclusion criteria (e.g., reviews) apply.

fMRI was performed during an observe/imitate emotional faces task (social cognitive processing). Participants were healthy adults (28 recruited, 20 analyzed), within adult age range. Not a review. Thus meets criteria for task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.
The study used fMRI during a social exclusion task (meets I1) but participants are described as 'male adolescents' with no adult (18–65) healthy group reported, so it fails inclusion criterion I2.

Functional MRI study of social interaction (telling jokes to make a listener laugh) involving self/other processing and reward—meets social-related task criterion. Abstract implies healthy adult participants though ages not specified; include for full-text to confirm demographics.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in which participants decided to read or share news articles; neural activity related to valuation, self-related processing, and perspective-taking was measured and associated with sharing — this meets I1. The abstract does not specify participant age range or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.
Study used macaque monkeys (non-human primates) in fMRI experiments — participants are not human adults. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria I1/I2 for healthy human participants aged 18–65.

Abstract reports collection of fMRI data while participants performed a social foraging task examining social influence and reward, satisfying I1. Participant health status and ages (18–65) are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion criterion I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Per screening rules, include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

Functional MRI was performed while healthy adult participants (trustees in a Trust Game) engaged in a social reciprocity task, directly addressing social processing. The sample is described as healthy adults, meeting age/group inclusion. This is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

fMRI study where participants imagined personally familiar others—this is a social cognition task, satisfying I1. The abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review.
fMRI study investigating social-emotional processing (schadenfreude and fremdscham) in healthy adult participants (N=34), meeting the requirement of a social-related task and healthy adult sample.

This paper is a quantitative review/meta-analysis synthesizing coordinates from prior fMRI studies (not reporting original fMRI data). It therefore meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses).

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind (social cognition) using belief tasks; participants appear to be healthy humans. Meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and likely I2 (healthy adult participants). Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.

Participants are children (ages 8–12); meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 18–65 (I2 not met). The study does involve an fMRI social task (I1), but the population does not match, so exclude.

The abstract describes a review/discussion of resting-state fMRI and social cognition rather than reporting original task-based fMRI data. It does not describe fMRI conducted while participants performed a social-related task (I1) and appears to be a review article, meeting exclusion criterion E1.

Abstract reports human fMRI experiments probing theory-of-mind/mentalizing (social cognition) during tasks, meeting I1. The abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adults (I2 uncertain). Per screening rules, include for full-text review to confirm I2.

fMRI was used to compare neural responses to romantic (social/affiliation) and sexual stimuli in healthy adult men (age within typical adult range). The task involves social-related processing (romantic/attachment), meeting I1 and I2 based on abstract information.

Abstract reports a single-case (n=1) fMRI study. While the task appears social-related (meets I1), inclusion criterion I2 requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 18–65); a single subject does not constitute a group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., reviews) apply.

The study investigates phonological memory and visuomotor processing of fingerspelling, not social-related processing or social communication per se; it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

This is a review article of fNIRS studies in Autism Spectrum Disorder (children/infants), not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (E1) and does not satisfy inclusion criteria (no fMRI, not healthy adult sample).

fMRI was used while participants performed social-related tasks (IAT about adultery and dating ratings), targeting affiliation/attachment and social decision-making. Participants are healthy adult males in romantic relationships. Thus meets I1 and I2 based on the abstract.

Abstract reports neural responses in human posterior superior temporal sulcus to stimuli depicting social interactions, indicating an fMRI study of social perception in humans. Authors and journal suggest healthy adult participants. Meets criteria for an fMRI social-related task and healthy adult sample.

This is an fMRI study (61 healthy adult White participants) performing a social perception/impression task involving race and socioeconomic status — a social-related processing task. It meets I1 (fMRI during social task) and I2 (healthy adults).

fMRI was used while participants viewed a moral dilemma about kinship, clearly a social-related task (meets I1). The abstract implies healthy adult subjects but does not report ages; insufficient age detail so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

The abstract describes an fMRI experiment in which healthy participants judged social orientation (facing toward/away) of point-light displays and human-like walkers — a social cognition task probing mirror and mentalizing systems. Not a review; meets I1 and I2.

The study used resting-state fMRI (fALFF) rather than a task-based fMRI scan during a social-related task. Inclusion criterion I1 requires an fMRI scan while participants perform a social task; this requirement is not met in the abstract. No exclusion criteria (e.g., review article) apply.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a social evaluation task (evaluating in-group/out-group politicians), satisfying the social-processing task requirement. Participants are described behaviorally with no clinical group; although exact ages aren’t given, the sample appears to be healthy adults—insufficient age detail would normally prompt full-text review, but criteria I1 and I2 are reasonably met based on the abstract.

Abstract reports a 7T fMRI rest-task-rest study in healthy adult participants using attachment-related narratives (a social/affiliation task), directly addressing social processing. Thus it meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adults). No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI was conducted during retrieval in the scanner for collaboratively vs individually learned labels, a social communication/understanding of others task; participants described as healthy human adults. Meets I1 and I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in 36 healthy adult participants investigating neural processing of social interactions (cooperativity and affectivity), meeting the review objective and inclusion criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study of joint action (leading/following/mutual) involving social-cognitive, somatosensory, and interpersonal processes. Participants are trained couple dancers (healthy adults). Study is original research, not a review. Satisfies fMRI social-task criterion and includes healthy adult participants.

Study used fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages 25–50), satisfying I2. However, the task (viewing erotic pictures/videos to assess sexual-orientation-related desire) is not clearly described as a social-related task per the listed constructs; abstract insufficient to confirm I1. Include for full-text review to determine whether stimuli/tasks qualify as social processing.
Study is an rsfMRI investigation in prairie voles (non-human animals). It does not involve human participants or task-based fMRI in healthy adults, so it fails inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

fMRI was used to measure neural responses while human participants discriminated affective vocalisations (a social-communication/perception task). The study reports behavioral and neural responses in healthy human participants; no exclusion criteria apply. Thus it meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy human participants, adults).

Participants are young children (4 and 6 years old); no adult participants aged 18–65 are included. Therefore the study does not meet inclusion criterion I2 requiring at least one healthy adult group. Abstract provides no evidence of an adult sample, so exclude.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI including social processing and emotion tasks in a large sample from the Human Connectome Project comprised of healthy adult participants, meeting both inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis. Sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Abstract reports fMRI during social-cognitive tasks (reflection on self and friend’s social attributes) in male adult participants, meeting the review’s focus on social-related processing. Participants are healthy adults (no disorders reported). Not a review/meta-analysis. Thus satisfies I1 and I2.

This is a narrative review/book chapter summarizing behavioral and neuroimaging literature, not an original fMRI study reporting data from participants. It does not describe an fMRI scan of healthy adults performing social tasks, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a narrative review/book chapter about adolescent social influence and developmental neuroscience; it does not report original fMRI data collected in healthy adults (18–65) and therefore does not meet the review's inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining perception of social interactions (dyadic interactions vs non-interactive actions), meeting I1. The abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review.
Participants are children and adolescents (ages 8–17); no adult (18–65) healthy participant group is reported, so the study does not meet inclusion criterion I2.

This is a review article (Annual Review of Neuroscience) discussing neural mechanisms across primates; the abstract describes synthesis and theory rather than reporting original fMRI data in healthy adult humans. It meets exclusion as a review article.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a social decision-making task (modified prisoner's dilemma) examining social cognition/ToM neural responses. Not a review. Thus meets functional MRI social-task criterion and includes healthy adults.

Abstract reports an independent task-based fMRI study comparing appraisal of social vs. non-social images, matching the review objective of social-related fMRI processing. However, the abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adult status (18–65); include for full-text review to confirm I2.

Study reports fMRI during an emotion perception task (facial/vocal/bimodal), which is social communication/perception of others (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

fMRI was used while healthy human participants made social interaction decisions (free vs. controlled choices), assessing social cognitions and neural correlates of perception/understanding of others; participants described as healthy adults. Not a review.

fMRI study where participants categorized prosodic expressions to infer speakers' communicative intentions (social communication), meeting the social-related task requirement. Abstract does not report participant ages, so inclusion regarding age cannot be fully confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review.

Abstract describes an fMRI study examining agentic self-evaluation and neural correlates (dorsolateral PFC, thalamus), which is social cognition/perception of self—meets I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adults, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm I2.

fMRI was used while participants evaluated social attributes of faces (perceived intelligence and friendliness), which is social processing (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met in abstract.

Single-case report of an 8-year-old child with massive frontal lesions; not a study of healthy adults (18–65). fMRI was used but not reported as a social-related task in healthy adult participants. Does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

Participants are children aged 8–12, so the study does not include healthy adult participants aged 18–65 and fails inclusion criterion I2. Although it uses fMRI for social tasks (I1), it does not meet the age requirement for this review.

fMRI study with 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic accuracy task (continuous rating of others’ emotional states), which is social processing (perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adults (within 18–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion.

The sample comprises adolescent boys (internet-addicted and non-addicted), not healthy adults aged 18–65, so the study does not meet I2 despite using fMRI on social-cognitive tasks (I1). No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply, but absence of an adult healthy group excludes it from the review.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and therefore does not meet inclusion criterion I1. It does include healthy adult controls (I2), but the review requires task-based social processing. Excluded on that basis.
Study uses fMRI in preterm infants (31–36 weeks PMA) studying sensorimotor somatotopy, not social processing and not healthy adults 18–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

Title and abstract explicitly report fMRI investigations of social concepts (people and social terms), addressing social processing. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text to confirm I2.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI including a social cognition task domain, satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample.

Participants are adolescents (ages 14–18). Inclusion criterion I2 requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 18–65. Although the study used an fMRI social-reward task (meets I1), the sample does not meet the adult age range, so exclude.

Task-based fMRI study (double-blind, placebo-controlled) in 55 healthy young men viewing attachment-related erotic and fearful social scenes; directly examines social-related processing in healthy adults.

Event-related fMRI was collected while participants performed a mind-perception task and related social attention was examined, satisfying I1 (social-related fMRI). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.

Study used macaque (non-human primate) subjects for fMRI; does not involve human participants aged 18–65 and therefore does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2. Exclude based on participant population mismatch.

This article is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation) of 28 fMRI studies in psychopaths, not a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Exclude per E1 (systematic reviews/meta-analyses).

This article is a narrative review summarizing infant fMRI findings and theoretical mechanisms rather than reporting original fMRI data in healthy adult participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews (E1).

Study used fMRI during an emotional face recognition task (processing own child’s facial emotions), a social-processing task. Adult mothers included a healthy control group (mothers without ELM). Thus it meets I1 and I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI task probing recall of relationship episodes (self/others) in 35 healthy individuals—fits social-related processing and fMRI (I1). Age range (18–65) is not reported in the abstract, so inclusion should be confirmed at full-text stage (I2 not verifiable from abstract). Include for full-text review to verify participant ages and other details.

Abstract suggests neural effects of oxytocin on social stimuli (anterior insula) but does not explicitly state fMRI or participant characteristics. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

fMRI study where 16 volunteers viewed and processed verbal and non-verbal social interactions, fulfilling I1. The abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; include for full-text review.

This article is a review of task-based functional neuroimaging studies in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults; it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews (E1).

The article is explicitly a review and meta-analysis of social cognition in PTSD rather than an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses).

fMRI study where participants evaluated faces varying by race and socioeconomic status (social perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises 61 adult (white male) participants, indicating healthy adult group. Meets criteria I1 and I2 based on abstract information.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of brain responses to faces, voices, and combined emotional expressions—clearly a social perception/understanding of others task. The abstract does not state participant health status or ages (18–65), so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (learning others' trustworthiness) involving healthy younger and older participants. It meets I1 (social-related task during fMRI) and appears to meet I2 (includes a healthy younger adult group likely within 18–65). No exclusion criteria apply.

The study used fMRI during joint leader–follower interactions (a social-related task) and recruited healthy skilled dancers (adult participants), meeting the review’s focus on social processing in healthy adults. Abstract indicates task-based fMRI and healthy subject groups, so it should be included for full-text review to confirm ages and health details.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than a task-based fMRI paradigm assessing social-related processing. The review requires functional MRI during a social-related task. Participants are healthy emerging adults (ages ~20–25), so I2 is satisfied but I1 is not.

fMRI study measuring neural representations of others' mental states—clearly a social-related task (Perception and Understanding of Others). Abstract reports human male and female participants but does not specify ages or explicitly state health status, so include for full-text review to confirm criterion I2 (healthy adults 18–65). No exclusion criteria met from abstract.

Study participants are children with NVLD or ASD and typically developing children, not healthy adults aged 18–65, so it fails inclusion criterion I2 (adult healthy sample). The abstract also does not clearly describe task-based fMRI of social processing. Exclude based on participant age/group mismatch.

This is a narrative review of resting-state fMRI findings and manipulations in ASD, not an original fMRI study of social-task performance in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (E1).

Abstract reports fMRI scanning during an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social decision-making task), satisfying I1. The sample (20 male participants) is described but health status and ages are not explicitly stated in the abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; include for full-text review to confirm participant health/age eligibility.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing) to map a mentalizing network and relies on intraoperative stimulation; it does not report an fMRI scan during a social-related task (fails I1). Participant group appears to be clinical (intraoperative), so healthy adult inclusion is unclear. No systematic review/meta-analysis criteria met.
Study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) and participants are adolescents (mean ~14.5, range 10–18), not healthy adults aged 18–65. Therefore it does not meet I1 or I2.

This article is a multi-method review/meta-analysis synthesizing lesion, TMS, MVPA, and Neurosynth evidence rather than reporting original fMRI scans of healthy adult participants. It meets exclusion criterion E1.

Study used fMRI during a social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy subjects randomized to intranasal oxytocin or placebo — meets the review objective. Ages not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age range (18–65).

Abstract reports neural (amygdala/prefrontal) responses to trust-related interpersonal stimuli in BPD versus controls, implying an fMRI social-processing task and inclusion of a healthy control group. The abstract does not explicitly state scanning parameters or participant ages (18–65), so include for full-text review to confirm methods and age range.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in 93 healthy males performing a Taylor aggression paradigm involving social provocation and decisions about retaliatory behavior (social cognition/perception of others). Participants are healthy adults, satisfying inclusion. No exclusion criteria apply.

Abstract describes dual-fMRI hyperscanning while pairs performed an interactive social-exchange task, meeting I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or that they were healthy adults, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.

This is an fMRI study using an interpersonal pleasant touch paradigm addressing social reward/processing, and includes a matched non-using healthy control group of adults. Thus it meets I1 (social-related task with fMRI) and I2 (healthy participants aged 18–65 present). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Study used a sample of early adolescents (ages 10.5–13.4), not adults 18–65, and used resting-state fMRI and MRS rather than a task-based social fMRI paradigm. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.
fMRI was conducted during spontaneous conversation and repetition tasks (social-related processing), and the study includes an age-matched typically developing healthy control group (young adults).

Abstract reports task-based fMRI during a theory-of-mind (social cognition) task, satisfying I1. Participants are described as younger and older adults but age ranges are not specified, so it is unclear whether a healthy 18–65 group is present; include for full-text review to confirm I2.
This is an animal study using Fmr1 knockout mice and pharmacological intervention; no human participants or human fMRI social-task data are reported, so it fails inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

fMRI was used to identify and modulate a pSTS region responsive to dynamic facial expressions—a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not state participant health status or ages, so inclusion criterion I2 is unclear; include for full-text review to confirm demographics and health.

The study used task-free (resting-state) fMRI rather than an fMRI social-related task, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. Although typically-developing controls are present (I2), the absence of a social task excludes it from this review.

fMRI hyperscanning study of live mutual eye contact—a social interaction task—conducted in human adult pairs. The abstract reports task-related neural activation and connectivity during eye contact, meeting the fMRI social-processing requirement. Participants are described as human adults (healthy sample), satisfying the participant age/health criterion.

fMRI study where participants viewed face images and performed perceptual/recognition tasks—fits social processing domain (Perception/Understanding of Others). Participants are human (male and female); abstract does not state ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI during live reciprocal social interactions (human-human vs human-robot), directly addressing social processing and reporting 21 scanned participants. Participant ages/health status are not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was used while participants observed human and robot agents experiencing pain/pleasure, assessing empathy — a social cognitive process. Participants (n=26) were healthy adults. The study meets criteria for social-related fMRI task and includes healthy adult participants. Not a review.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants watched a narrator using co-speech gestures, addressing social communication and semantic processing in an ecologically valid social interaction. Twenty healthy participants (adults) were tested, satisfying both criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of socioemotional processing (empathy and anxiety), which fits social-related processing (I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (18–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to assess I2.

Study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, so it does not meet I1. Age range is across the lifespan (not specified as 18–65), so I2 is not clearly satisfied. No exclusion criteria (E1) apply.

fMRI study using the Cyberball paradigm (social inclusion) satisfies social-related task requirement. The sample includes a healthy control group (17 HC) alongside clinical groups; participants appear to be adults. Thus I1 and I2 are met based on the abstract.

The study reports fMRI BOLD responses to animacy perception—a basic social-perception process—so it addresses social-related processing (I1). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.
This article is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies (not an original fMRI study of participants), meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

The study used resting-state fMRI (connectivity at rest) rather than a task-based fMRI during performance of a social-related task, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. Participants appear to be healthy adults (N=50).
Participants are children with ASD and age-matched typically developing children (not adults). No group of healthy adults (age 18–65) is included, so study fails inclusion criterion I2.

The study used fMRI while participants played a virtual ball-tossing game inducing social exclusion (a social-related task) and reports neural correlates modulated by social support. The sample comprises 71 healthy female participants. Thus it satisfies I1 (fMRI during a social task) and I2 (healthy participant group).

The study reports fMRI data including social perception and reasoning tasks (social-related processing) performed by 78 individuals, indicating relevant task-based fMRI in humans. No clinical populations are reported, implying healthy adult participants.

fMRI study investigating processing of dynamic facial expressions (social communication/perception) in a participant sample (n=51). Abstract indicates a social-related task and likely healthy adult participants; age range not reported, so full text review is needed to confirm I2. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study investigating neural processing of social (dyadic) interactions, satisfying I1. Abstract does not specify participant age range or explicit statement that participants were healthy adults (I2 unclear). Given insufficient participant detail, include for full-text review to confirm I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment (N=31) measuring neural responses to disfigured faces—a social perception task (perception/understanding of others). It likely used healthy adult participants, though ages/health not explicitly stated; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study using vocal emotional stimuli (social communication/perception) with 36 healthy participants; meets criteria of performing a social-related task (vocal emotion processing) and including healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract, so included for full-text review.

The abstract describes a review of human neuroimaging literature and theoretical discussion of cerebellar function rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. It is therefore a review article and meets exclusion criterion E1.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsfMRI) before/after rTMS rather than an fMRI task assessing social-related processing, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. Healthy adult participants are included (I2).

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social fMRI paradigm, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (fMRI during a social-related task). Although healthy controls were included (I2), the primary imaging was resting-state, so exclude for the review focused on task-based social processing.

The study used rtfMRI neurofeedback for hippocampal self-regulation in healthy volunteers, not a social-related task or paradigm probing social cognition/interaction. Although participants are healthy adults (I2 satisfied), the abstract does not describe any social processing task (I1 not met). No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

The study used EEG-fMRI during a color discrimination (visual) task and investigates visual gamma and related networks — not social processing. It does not address social-related constructs (I1 not met). Participants appear healthy but lack of social task means it is irrelevant to the review objective.

The study used fMRI during a social trust task (meets I1) but the healthy control group were adolescents aged 13–19, so they do not meet the required healthy adult age range (18–65) specified in I2. Therefore it should be excluded.
