The abstract describes a review/meta-analytic study (combining PubMed literature search, Neurosynth meta-analytic database, and resting-state connectivity analyses) rather than reporting new primary fMRI data from participants. This meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review or meta-analysis).

The study used fMRI while participants played the prisoners' dilemma (a social/interpersonal decision-making task), and included a healthy control group alongside patients. Thus it satisfies I1 (task during fMRI is social) and I2 (healthy adults included). Not a review article.

Participants are adolescents (age 16–17); inclusion criterion I2 requires at least one group of healthy adults (18–65). Although the fMRI task addresses social-related processing (I1 met), the sample does not include adults, so the study is excluded.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of emotional facial expression processing (a social task), satisfying I1. The abstract does not state whether healthy adult control participants (I2) were included, so inclusion requires full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI social-processing paradigm. Although behavioral measures of social cognition (emotion/sarcasm recognition) were assessed and a healthy control group was included (I2), the absence of an fMRI social-related task means it does not meet I1.

Abstract reports an fMRI study probing honesty-based trustworthiness impressions and predicting trust behavior, meeting I1. Participant health status and ages (I2) are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion cannot be fully confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify that at least one group are healthy adults (18–65).

The study included only participants with alcohol use disorder (no healthy control group). Inclusion criterion I2 requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 18–65. Although it uses fMRI with emotional face processing (I1), lack of a healthy sample excludes it from the review.

Functional MRI was used while participants observed and discriminated others' hand actions (perception/understanding of others — a social process). The study includes a healthy adult group (n=31). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI during auditory (voice) stimulation addressing voice processing and social cognition, meeting I1. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

Study uses multi-voxel pattern analysis of neural representations of social touch (implies fMRI) addressing social processing. Abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) was included, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports resting-state fMRI in toddlers with autism (ASD) and an ASD subtype identified by eye-tracking. No task-based social fMRI and participants are not healthy adults (18–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

fMRI was used while participants recalled museum displays, and the study addresses collective memory and medial prefrontal cortex involvement in social cognition—meeting I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or clearly state they are healthy adults (18–65), so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

Abstract clearly states this article is a literature review of hallucinogens and entactogens on social processing; it is a review article, meeting exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses). No original fMRI experimental data are described in the abstract.

This study is about developmental and sleep questionnaires for ASD screening in children/toddlers and does not report any fMRI data or involve healthy adult participants (age 18–65). It does not meet the review’s fMRI or adult healthy participant criteria.

This is a machine-learning methods paper on probabilistic graphical modeling for multi-view bipartite graph clustering. The abstract does not describe any fMRI data, human participants, or social-related tasks, so it does not meet the review inclusion criteria.

The abstract is a narrative review/perspective of naturalistic fMRI approaches rather than reporting original fMRI data on participants. It summarizes existing findings and methods, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

This article is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies (systematic synthesis), which meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses). Excluded based on article type despite relevance to social cognition in healthy adults.

The abstract identifies the paper as a critical appraisal/review of naturalistic stimuli in neuroscience rather than a primary fMRI study. It does not report fMRI data from healthy adult participants. Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review/meta-analysis/review).

Abstract identifies the article as a review (‘The present review’). It is not a primary fMRI study reporting data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks, so it meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses).

This article is a review of fMRI findings in autism spectrum disorders (a systematic review), not an original fMRI study of healthy adults performing social tasks. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract describes an overview/chapter summarizing and summarizing evidence on oxytocin in schizophrenia (a review/narrative chapter), not an original fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

This article is a review/reappraisal of social cognition in multiple sclerosis and discusses neuropsychological and neuroimaging studies rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. It meets exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.
Abstract reports an fMRI study probing social reward and threat processing (social-related task) and includes a healthy control group aged 50–60 within the 18–65 range. Thus it meets I1 and I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI task probing social cognition (inferring characters’ mental states from film extracts) and includes healthy control groups. Age range (18–65) not specified in abstract, so full-text review needed to confirm I2. Included for full-text screening.

Abstract reports neural processing of social vs non-social anticipation and feedback in borderline personality disorder, implying a social-related neuroimaging task and likely a healthy control group; however, the modality (fMRI) and explicit mention of healthy participants are not stated. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and presence of 18–65 healthy adults.
Abstract explicitly states this article is a review of findings to-date (a review/meta-analysis). It is therefore a systematic review/meta-analysis and meets exclusion criterion E1.

Abstract is a narrative review of neuroimaging findings in autism (discusses multiple imaging modalities and studies in autistic patients) rather than an original fMRI study with healthy adult participants. Therefore it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses (E1).

This is a narrative review article summarizing social neuroscience in psychiatry rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults; it meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses).

This article is a systematic review (title and abstract state this) summarizing trials in schizophrenia, not a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review).

Abstract describes a literature review of fMRI reliability rather than reporting original fMRI data from participants performing a social task. Thus it meets the exclusion criterion for review articles and does not provide primary data on social processing in healthy adults.

This article is described as a mini-review synthesizing MRI and genetic findings (not reporting original fMRI data). It is therefore a review article, meeting exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses).

This is a narrative review of semantic dementia (neuroimaging, genetics, pathology), not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Abstract indicates patient-focused research and does not report healthy adult fMRI social tasks.

Abstract addresses neurobiological correlates of social-cognitive (empathy) alterations in psychopathy, suggesting social-related processing; however it does not explicitly state fMRI methods or presence of healthy control group. Insufficient methodological detail in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm I1 and I2.

This article is a narrative review of eye/gaze processing and neuroimaging findings rather than an original fMRI study with participants performing a social task; it is therefore not eligible (review article).

fMRI study of self–other judgments (social-related processing) meeting I1; includes a typically developing healthy adult control group (age-matched young adults) meeting I2. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social inclusion/exclusion paradigm with emotional support in healthy undergraduate participants (n=46), addressing social-related processing (social exclusion and support). Meets inclusion criteria for task and participant population; no exclusion criteria evident from abstract.

The abstract reports fMRI during a dyadic social interaction task in human subjects, directly addressing social processing (I1). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy, so full-text review is needed to confirm I2.

This paper is a coordinate-based Activation Likelihood Estimation meta-analysis of neuroimaging studies, i.e., a meta-analysis rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults. It therefore meets exclusion criterion E1 (meta-analysis).

Abstract examines motion perception of biological objects (faces), a social-cognition relevant task, and includes an age-matched healthy control group (N=67). However, the abstract does not specify that functional MRI was used. Include for full-text review to confirm I1 (fMRI during a social task).

Abstract reports fMRI studies of theory-of-mind (mentalizing), a social cognitive task, but does not specify whether a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine presence of healthy participants; include for full-text review.

Abstract is a review article synthesizing behavioral and imaging studies of emotion and facial affect in schizophrenia rather than reporting an original fMRI study in healthy adults; therefore it meets the review exclusion (E1).

fMRI BOLD was used while participants performed a socio-emotional face appraisal task (“Do you like this face?”), which is a social-related task. The study includes a healthy control group. Ages not specified in the abstract, so full-text should confirm participants are 18–65.

Abstract explicitly describes a meta-analysis of over 200 fMRI studies. This meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses), so the study should be excluded based on abstract alone.

This paper is a voxel-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis/systematic review), so it meets exclusion criterion E1. Although it concerns fMRI of social/maternal processing, it is not an original empirical fMRI study of healthy adults and therefore should be excluded based on the abstract.

The paper is a multimodal coordinate-based meta-analysis (CBMA) of fMRI and VBM studies of first-degree relatives of schizophrenia patients. As a meta-analysis, it meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review or meta-analysis) and should be excluded based on the abstract.

The study used fMRI during a task probing understanding of others' regret, which fits social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Per screening guidance, include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

This is a review chapter summarizing oxytocin effects in ASD (neuroimaging and behavioral evidence), not an original fMRI study reporting task-based social processing in healthy adults. It does not present fMRI data from healthy 18–65 participants and therefore does not meet the review objective.

Abstract lacks detail about task modality and participant groups. Title focuses on schizophrenia and does not state whether an fMRI social-related task was used or whether healthy adult controls (age 18–65) were included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

The study reports an fMRI experiment in which healthy adult participants made self-descriptiveness judgments (social self-processing) while scanned, matching the review objective. It is empirical original research (not a review).

Abstract reports fMRI studies of social perception (visual analysis of others’ actions/intentions) in typically developing adults and developmental work; thus it involves an fMRI social task and includes healthy adult participants. It is a program summary of original fMRI research, not a systematic review/meta-analysis from the abstract.

This article is a review (title and abstract indicate it synthesizes neuroimaging studies) rather than an original fMRI study reporting data; therefore it meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses). The abstract provides no original fMRI data on healthy participants.

Resting-state fMRI in children (ages 7–12) with ASD and typically developing controls; no task-based social processing and no healthy adult (18–65) sample. Therefore it fails inclusion criteria I1 and I2. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.
This article is a meta-analysis of neuroimaging studies (title and abstract state meta-analysis) rather than a primary fMRI study of participants. Excluded per E1 (systematic reviews/meta-analyses).

The paper is a narrative review discussing neuroimaging and behavioral studies in high-functioning autism rather than an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide primary fMRI data on healthy participants.

This study reports resting-state fMRI in children with ASD and typically developing controls (from ABIDE); no task-based social processing fMRI and participants are not healthy adults (18–65). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

Abstract reports the authors performed three meta-analyses of fMRI studies, i.e., a meta-analysis/systematic review. This meets exclusion criterion E1. Although lesion patient data are included, the primary fMRI component is a meta-analysis rather than original fMRI scanning of healthy adults.

Abstract describes use of functional neuroimaging (simultaneous fMRI of two individuals) to study joint attention and discusses neural substrates of prosocial behavior, indicating task-based fMRI of social processing. Participant health/age not specified; include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult group.

Abstract reports resting-state fMRI in individuals with autism spectrum conditions and does not describe a task-based social processing paradigm. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (task-based social-related fMRI) and is ineligible for this review.
This paper is a large-scale meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study of participants performing social tasks; exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews/meta-analyses) applies.

fMRI was used during a face-encoding task (a social cognition paradigm), and the study included an age- and gender-matched healthy control group. The abstract does not state participant ages (18–65) explicitly, so full-text review is needed to confirm the age criterion.

fMRI was conducted while participants viewed social vs non-social stimuli (meets I1). The study included a matched healthy control group (meets I2). Age range not stated in abstract but presence of healthy adult controls is likely; no exclusion criteria apply. Include for full-text review to confirm ages if needed.

Abstract examines neural signatures of affective self- vs. other-touch in adults including neurotypical controls, addressing social-related processing and including a healthy adult group. However, the abstract does not explicitly state that fMRI was used nor specify participant ages, so full-text review is needed to confirm I1 and age range (I2).

Abstract does not state that task-based fMRI was used nor that healthy adults (age 18–65) were included; focuses on bvFTD patients and network centrality. Information is insufficient to confirm I1 or I2, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract does not specify a social-related task or participants’ ages (ABIDE I often contains resting-state data). Insufficient information to confirm I1 (task-based social processing) and I2 (healthy adults 18–65). Include for full-text review to verify task type and participant ages.

fMRI was conducted during an empathy task, a social-related process, and the study includes a healthy control group. Age range for healthy participants (18–65) is not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm I2.

Abstract is ambiguous. Title and mention of default and mirror networks suggest a neuroimaging (fMRI) investigation of social processes (possible I1), but the abstract does not state that an fMRI task was performed nor whether a healthy adult control group (I2) was included. Insufficient information to determine inclusion/exclusion from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI with a social-emotional task (satisfies I1) but includes only schizophrenia patient groups and no healthy adult control group, so it fails inclusion criterion I2. No exclusion criteria (e.g., reviews) apply.

The abstract describes a systematic review of 208 fMRI and DTI studies in ASD, not an original fMRI study with primary participants. Excluded per E1 (systematic reviews/meta-analyses). The abstract does not report primary data on healthy adult participants performing social tasks.

fMRI was conducted while participants processed emotional faces, a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others (I1). Abstract implies single-subject analyses and does not mention clinical samples; typical fMRI study of healthy participants, so likely meets I2. No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages and health status.
This study used resting-state fMRI in ASD patients and controls, not a task-based fMRI paradigm of social processing, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (task-based social-related fMRI).

fMRI study where participants made social judgments of faces (trustworthiness), which is a social-processing task. The study includes a nonclinical healthy control group (adults) alongside XXY participants, satisfying inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

The study is an Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) meta-analysis of fMRI studies, i.e., a meta-analysis rather than a primary fMRI experiment. Exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses) applies.

fMRI was used during a social-related task (emotional faces) and the study includes neurotypical control participants. The abstract does not specify ages of participants, so full-text review is needed to confirm they meet the 18–65 healthy adult criterion.

fMRI social-judgment task with matched healthy control group is reported, satisfying the requirement for a social-related fMRI task (I1). The abstract does not specify participant ages (18–65), so age criterion (I2) cannot be fully confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify ages.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task) comparing schizophrenia patients and controls; it does not test social-related processing during a task. Thus it fails the required inclusion criterion I1. No exclusion criteria (e.g., review/meta-analysis) apply.

The study used fMRI while participants passively watched a cinematic social-affective scene probing Theory of Mind and embodied-affiliation processes (meets I1). It includes a healthy adult control group alongside schizophrenia patients (meets I2). The abstract is original research (not a review) and provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI was performed in healthy adult participants (15 males). The task involved fear-inducing visual stimuli which likely taps social processing (e.g., perception of others’ fearful expressions), but the abstract does not explicitly state social stimuli. Given insufficient detail to be certain, include for full-text review to confirm.

The abstract describes a narrative review of fMRI research and brain development in infants, not a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It is a review article, meeting exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses).

Participants were male children/adolescents aged 10–18; inclusion criterion I2 requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 18–65. Although I1 (fMRI social task) is met, no healthy adult group is present, so the study is excluded.

The study used task-based fMRI of social cognition (affective ToM, emotion recognition, neutral face processing) and included a matched healthy control group, satisfying I1. The abstract confirms healthy participants but does not report participant ages (18–65) explicitly, so I2 is uncertain; include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.
The title and abstract describe this work as an fMRI meta-analysis. Exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses) is met, so the study should be excluded.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (not a task-based social processing paradigm) and participants are children including ASD, not healthy adults aged 18–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria I1 (task-based social fMRI) or I2 (healthy adult participants).

Abstract reports an fMRI study of emotional prosody processing (a social communication task) comparing individuals with ASD and control participants. Thus it meets I1 (fMRI during social-related task) and I2 (includes a healthy control group). Age range of participants is not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm ages.

Abstract describes ERP research and reads like a review of emotion processing rather than reporting original fMRI data collected during a social task. It therefore does not meet the review’s focus on fMRI studies of social processing and appears to be a review article (exclude E1).

Abstract reports social-cognitive functional MRI tasks showing superior temporal sulcus activity, meeting the fMRI social-processing criterion. Participant health status and ages (18–65) are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets I2.

Study reports fMRI activation during a simple motor task in autistic patients and control subjects; the task is non-social and does not address social-related processing, so it fails inclusion criterion I1. Healthy controls are present but the task is not social. Not a review/meta-analysis.

The study used fMRI during the Human Connectome Project social cognition paradigm (a social task) and included a matched healthy control group (n=25). Thus it addresses social processing with fMRI and includes healthy adult participants, meeting I1 and I2.

This study used resting-state fMRI in a developmental sample (ages 14–26) and did not report a social-related task. It therefore does not meet the task-based social processing inclusion criterion (I1) or clearly focus on adults only (I2).

The study used fMRI concurrently with EEG during a group categorization task involving processing of emotional faces, meeting I1 (social-related fMRI task). The abstract does not report participant age or explicit healthy status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.

This is an fMRI study where 20 human volunteers performed a social-related task (simulating a third person’s feelings while viewing movies), addressing perception/understanding of others. Participants are healthy volunteers. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study using a baby-cry task that probes attachment/affiliation and self/other processing (social-related constructs). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15) alongside a depressed group. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract discusses social cognition and brain network topology but does not specify that functional MRI was conducted during a social-related task or report ages/healthy adult group. Information is insufficient to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine if I1 and I2 are met.

Abstract reports fMRI findings from 22 typically developing adults performing a social attribution (mentalizing) task using the DISC stimuli, satisfying both fMRI social task and healthy adult sample criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (intranasal oxytocin) with no social-related task performed, so it does not meet I1 (task-based social processing). Participants are healthy adult women (I2 met), but absence of a social task excludes it.

fMRI experiments examined voice recognition, a form of social communication/perception (meets I1). Abstract reports matched control participants (healthy adults) alongside two cases, satisfying presence of a healthy adult group (I2).

Abstract lacks critical details: it does not state whether fMRI was conducted during a social-related task or whether healthy control participants (age 18–65) were included. Due to insufficient information to determine eligibility, include for full-text review to assess I1 and I2.

Abstract addresses social processing (face-processing networks) relevant to review, but does not state whether fMRI was used or whether healthy control group (age 18–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review.

fMRI was performed during a social cognition (theory of mind/empathy) task, satisfying I1. The abstract does not explicitly state participants were healthy adults aged 18–65, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify participant health/age.

Study involves pediatric participants (childhood stroke) and uses resting-state connectivity rather than a task-based fMRI of social processing. Does not meet I1 (task-based social fMRI) or I2 (healthy adults 18–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task involving social-related processing, so inclusion criterion I1 is not met. It does include healthy controls (I2), but the review requires task-based social fMRI.

fMRI study examining how participants learn about others' preferences (social cognition/perception of others) during a task, meeting I1. The abstract does not report participant ages or explicit health status, so I2 cannot be fully confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify.
fMRI was used to investigate neural correlates of social understanding (a social-related task) in adults; study includes a matched healthy control group (adults). Therefore meets criteria I1 and I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social-cognitive processes (attentional and attributional biases), meeting I1. Participant details (presence of healthy adults) are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion of healthy 18–65 group (I2) cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review to verify. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study used fMRI during a social (Theory-of-Mind) task (meets I1). However, the abstract only describes 47 patients with schizophrenia and does not clearly report a healthy adult control group (I2 not confirmed). Per instructions, include for full-text review to determine presence of healthy participants.

fMRI study in which participants performed social cognition tasks (face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM) during functional MRI; includes a healthy matched control group of adults. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI comparing MDD patients and healthy controls and did not report any task-based social processing paradigm; thus it does not meet I1. It does include healthy controls (I2), but absence of a social task excludes it from this review.
Abstract explicitly states this is a review article; no original fMRI data in healthy adults are reported. Excluded as a systematic review/meta-analysis (E1).

Study uses fMRI during facial emotion perception, a social-related task (meets I1). The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 18–65) was included; nonpsychotic relatives are not explicitly 'healthy controls.' Insufficient information to confirm I2, so include for full-text review.

This article is a quantitative review/meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation) of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study of participants performing tasks. It therefore meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review/meta-analysis).
Participants are children/adolescents (ASD and typically developing), not adults 18–65; although an fMRI social task was used (I1), no healthy adult group is present, so it does not meet I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI task probing social attribution (Theory of Mind), meeting I1. A healthy control group is present, but participant ages are not specified in the abstract so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review to verify age criteria.

fMRI task involved encoding facts about unfamiliar people (social processing relevant to perception/understanding of others). Study used human participants (healthy adult sample implied) and reports task-based fMRI and resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract reports fMRI experiments investigating neural correlates of biological motion perception, a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). Study includes healthy participants alongside schizophrenia group. Thus it meets fMRI social task requirement and includes healthy adults.

Abstract reports neural responses to social/emotional stimuli in schizophrenia and depression, implying a social-related task and likely inclusion of healthy control participants, but it does not explicitly state fMRI or participant ages. Insufficient detail to confirm imaging modality or healthy adult group; include for full-text review.

Task-based fMRI examining action-intention judgment (a social-related process), meeting I1. The study includes a typically developing (healthy) comparison group, but the abstract does not report participants' ages to confirm they are 18–65 (I2). Due to insufficient age information, include for full-text review to confirm age criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI social cognition paradigm in schizophrenia patients, satisfying I1. It does not specify whether healthy control participants (age 18–65) were included, so I2 is unclear. No exclusion criteria met; include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy adults.
Abstract reports resting-state fMRI (no social task performed) and includes only MS patients with no healthy adult control group reported. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

This study reports dual MEG (magnetoencephalography) hyperscanning with an audiovisual link, not functional MRI. It therefore does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (fMRI during a social-related task). Abstract provides sufficient information to exclude based on modality mismatch.
Resting-state fMRI in children/adolescents with ASD; no task-based social processing (fails I1) and no healthy adult (18–65) group (fails I2). Not a review/meta-analysis (E1 not applicable).

Abstract reports BOLD fMRI during tasks targeting affective and cognitive Theory of Mind (a social cognition task), and includes 23 healthy participants. This satisfies I1 and I2. Age range not specified in abstract, but presence of a healthy participant group justifies inclusion for full-text review.

The study reports functional MRI during a false-belief (theory-of-mind) task—a social cognition paradigm—and includes healthy comparison groups (480 adults), meeting task and healthy adult participant criteria. It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

The study used fMRI with a threat reactivity task involving socially threatening images (social processing) and includes a matched healthy control group of adult women, satisfying the review’s requirements. No exclusion criteria apply.

The abstract explicitly states this article is a review of genetics and neuroimaging in autism rather than an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults; it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (E1).

Abstract describes a task-based fMRI study probing how people evaluate political beliefs—a form of social cognition (self/other processing). This satisfies I1. The abstract does not specify participant age range or explicit health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

Abstract reports neuroimaging effects of intranasal oxytocin on amygdala reactivity but does not specify that a functional MRI was performed during a social-related task nor whether the human sample were healthy adults aged 18–65. Information is insufficient to confirm inclusion from the abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

Abstract does not specify an fMRI social task or the presence of healthy adult participants; insufficient information to determine inclusion. Include for full-text review to assess task type and participant groups.

The study used fMRI to measure neural responses during a social exclusion task (social pain), and enrolled 21 healthy volunteers—satisfying the requirement for a social-related fMRI task and a healthy adult sample. Abstract provides sufficient information to apply inclusion criteria.

Participants are children/adolescents (not healthy adults 18–65) and the fMRI examines auditory processing/connectivity rather than a social-related task; therefore the study does not meet inclusion criteria I1 and I2. It is not a systematic review/meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of joint attention (a social interaction task) in healthy adult participants (n=24), meeting both criteria: functional MRI during a social-related task and healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met.

Although fMRI during a social-related task is reported (I1), all participants are described as youth (ASD and typically-developing controls), so there is no healthy adult (age 18–65) group, failing I2. No exclusionary publication type applies.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of emotional sentence attribution (a social-related processing task), satisfying I1. The abstract does not state whether a healthy adult control group was included, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; per review rules, include for full-text review to determine presence of healthy participants.

fMRI was used to study dynamic processing of happy facial expressions and social interaction cues (a social-related task). The study includes a non-SPD comparison group (healthy controls). Full text should be checked for participant ages and other details.
The study used functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS), not functional MRI. Therefore inclusion criterion I1 (functional MRI scan) is not met, so the study is not eligible.

Study used fMRI during biological (body) motion processing—a social perception task—and included a group of healthy matched controls. Thus it meets I1 (fMRI during social-related task) and I2 (healthy participant group). No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult clinicians (ages 25–37) performed a live treatment task involving a patient confederate, assessing empathy/reward during a social interaction — a social-related task. Participants meet the healthy 18–65 criterion; no exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI was used during a face emotion discrimination task (social cognition/perception of others). The sample is a community group of individuals high vs. low in social anhedonia (healthy adult participants implied). Thus the study meets social-related fMRI task and includes healthy adults.

The study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. While it includes healthy control subjects (meets I2), it does not meet I1 (no social-related task during scanning), so it should be excluded.

fMRI study with participants performing an emotion-tracing task that engages social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract does not explicitly state ages/health status, but likely healthy adults; include for full-text verification.

fMRI was conducted during a legal decision-making task involving social cognition (perception/understanding of others), satisfying I1. The abstract does not state participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract—include for full-text review to verify.

The abstract reports fMRI decoding applied to the HCP dataset, explicitly mentioning performance on social cognition tasks. The HCP consists of healthy adult participants, so the study involves fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults.

The abstract describes a meta-analysis across 12 fMRI studies, i.e., a systematic review/meta-analysis. This meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses). Exclude based on abstract alone.

The study used fMRI during a visual perspective-taking task (a social-cognitive process) and included a group of age- and gender-matched healthy volunteers, satisfying the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. The abstract provides clear evidence of both criteria, warranting inclusion for full-text data extraction.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining processing of others' physical and emotional pain (social cognition/Theory of Mind), using healthy participant groups; matches social-related task and healthy adult sample. Not a review or meta-analysis. Sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria based on abstract.

fMRI was used while participants played the iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma, a social task probing responses to unreciprocated cooperation (meets I1). Large samples of men and women were randomized to treatments, implying healthy adult participants; include for full-text to confirm age range and health status (meets I2 based on abstract information).

This is an fMRI study manipulating implied social presence and reports changes in networks tied to social cognition, self-processing, and theory of mind, so it addresses social-related processing. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so inclusion criterion I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract—full-text needed.

Study II used functional MRI during a social gaze/interaction paradigm (social reward processing) and included a healthy control group. Therefore it satisfies the fMRI social-task requirement and includes healthy adults.

Abstract reports event-related fMRI responses to positive social stimuli, satisfying I1. It does not specify whether a healthy adult (18–65) control group was included; participants appear to be depressed pre- and post-treatment. Insufficient information to determine I2, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigates implicit facial emotion recognition, a social processing task (meets I1). Abstract does not clearly state that participants were healthy adults aged 18–65 or whether a healthy control group was included, so inclusion status for I2 is unclear. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult participants and age range.

fMRI recorded while participants observed dynamic and static facial expressions (social perception task), and the study included age- and sex-matched typically developing control group. This meets I1 and likely I2; age range not explicitly stated in abstract so include for full-text review to confirm 18–65.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and investigates limbic networks in AD/MCI; does not address social processing tasks in healthy adults. Abstract does not report task-based social fMRI, so it fails inclusion criterion I1. No exclusion criteria (E1) apply.

fMRI study using an event-related task probing empathy/affective appraisal to humans and animals (social cognition). Recruited healthy adult groups (omnivores, vegetarians, vegans) matched for sex and age, satisfying requirement for healthy participants. Abstract provides sufficient task and population info to meet inclusion and warrants full-text review.

Participants are school-age children (ages 9–13), not adults 18–65 required by inclusion criterion I2. Although the study uses fMRI on a social (theory-of-mind) task (meets I1), it fails the age criterion, so it should be excluded.

Abstract reports fMRI data collected while participants viewed dynamic facial expressions (a social cognition task). The abstract does not specify participant health status or age range, so inclusion requires full-text review to confirm healthy adults (18–65).

fMRI was conducted while participants performed a Theory of Mind (social cognition) task, meeting I1. The study includes a healthy control group alongside bipolar patients, meeting I2; ages 18–65 are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

This study used resting-state fMRI without participants performing a social-related task, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. Although healthy controls are included, absence of task-based social processing excludes it from the review.

Participants are adolescents (high-functioning adolescents with ASD and typically developing adolescents), not adults aged 18–65, so criterion I2 (healthy participants age 18–65) is not met. The study is not a review/meta-analysis.

Study used fMRI during face-processing (social-related task: perception/recognition of others) and included healthy control subjects (adult controls) compared to a clinical case. This satisfies I1 and I2. It is an original empirical study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study with human participants examining neural coding of dynamic head turns—a social attention cue—so it meets the review's social-processing fMRI requirement (I1). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; per protocol, include for full-text review to verify sample. No exclusion criteria met in the abstract.

This article is an ALE meta-analysis of fMRI studies examining social-cognitive deficits after traumatic brain injury, i.e., a meta-analysis rather than an original fMRI study. Per exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses), exclude.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition (social judgments) in ASD and SPD, satisfying I1. The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) was included, so inclusion criterion I2 is uncertain. Per instructions, include for full-text review when information is insufficient.

The study used fMRI while participants (adults) contemplated social interactions—a social-related task—and included a matched healthy control group of adults alongside an autism group. Thus it meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult participants present). Not a review/meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social perception experiment and includes a healthy control group (21 adults) alongside a schizophrenia group. This satisfies I1 (social-related task fMRI) and I2 (healthy participants aged within adult range). No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study examining mentalizing (understanding others' beliefs/intentions) and motor simulation during listening to literary fiction; involves human participants (presumably healthy adults) performing social-related tasks. Abstract indicates neural processing of others' mental states, meeting social-processing criteria. No exclusion criteria met.

Study reports fMRI measurements while healthy adult women performed a social perception task (viewing animations of social interactions and attending to social relationships), directly addressing social-related processing. Sample consists of healthy adults (women not using hormonal contraception). Thus it meets I1 and I2.

Study participants are children with BCECTS; abstract reports pediatric sample and does not include a healthy adult (18–65) group, so it fails inclusion criterion I2. The fMRI fearful faces task meets I1, but absence of adults makes the study ineligible for this review.

Study used fMRI during a social task (feedback about being liked), and participants were aged 18–21 (within 18–65) with varying social anhedonia but not described as a clinical patient group. Thus it meets I1 and I2 and is not a review/meta-analysis.

Study used task-based fMRI of self/other personality judgments (meets I1) but the sample is adult male incarcerated offenders with no healthy adult (18–65) group mentioned, so I2 is not satisfied. Exclude based on absence of healthy participants in abstract.

The study used fMRI while participants performed the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, a social-cognitive/emotion-recognition task, in healthy young adult women. This satisfies I1 (social-related task during fMRI) and I2 (healthy participants aged 18–65). The abstract is primary research, not a review.

Participants are preschool-aged children with ASD and typically developing children; no healthy adult (age 18–65) group is included, so inclusion criterion I2 is not met. The study does use fMRI with a social perception task (I1 met) but lack of adult healthy participants excludes it.

Event-related fMRI during moral dilemma tasks (social processing) conducted; includes a healthy control group of adults matched for age. Abstract clearly satisfies social-related task imaging and presence of healthy participants.

The study used fMRI and examines action observation of others’ effort, addressing perception/understanding of others (a social-related construct). The abstract does not report participant health status or ages, so inclusion criterion I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to assess I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study probing self/other social-cognitive processing and representational maintenance, and includes a healthy control group alongside a BPD group. Thus it meets I1 (task-based fMRI of social-related processing) and I2 (at least one healthy adult group). No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study using a social-related self-referential task (judging trait adjectives about self/mother/president) and includes a healthy control group. The abstract does not report ages of controls, so include for full-text review to confirm they meet the 18–65 criterion.

Study reports an fMRI emotion-recognition task using facial expressions (social perception/communication) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=16). The abstract provides sufficient detail to satisfy inclusion criteria I1 and I2 and it is not a review/meta-analysis.

Study uses fMRI during social-cognition tasks (theory of mind) and includes a matched healthy control group. Thus it addresses social-related processing and has healthy adult controls, satisfying I1 and I2. Age range not explicitly stated in abstract but controls are age-matched to ALS patients (adult sample).

Study uses resting-state fMRI with no social-related task; does not meet inclusion criterion I1. It does include healthy controls (satisfies I2) but fails the required task-based social processing requirement. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

Abstract provides insufficient detail to confirm whether fMRI was conducted during a social-related task or whether healthy adult controls were included. The study addresses social cognition in ASD and likely involves fMRI and controls, so include for full-text review to determine I1 and I2.
Study used fMRI during a facial emotional processing task (a social-related task) in adults and included a matched healthy control group. This satisfies I1 and I2. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study used fMRI while participants observed risk-taking versus safe actions—a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others. Participants were healthy late adolescents aged 18.1–22.8, within the 18–65 range. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI studied irony comprehension, a social-cognition/social-communication task (meets I1). The study includes a healthy control group (15 female controls) alongside schizophrenia patients, satisfying I2. Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review.

Primary fMRI study administering a social cognitive (Theory of Mind) task (Why/How) in healthy adult participants; directly assesses perception/understanding of others using functional MRI, meeting inclusion criteria I1 and I2.
Resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and participants are male adolescents (not healthy adults aged 18–65). Therefore the study does not meet I1 or I2. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task). Inclusion criterion I1 requires that participants perform a social-related task during fMRI. Abstract indicates no task was performed, so it does not meet I1.

The study uses fMRI to assess Theory of Mind (a social-cognition task), and includes a healthy comparison group (‘healthy subjects’). Both inclusion criteria (fMRI social task and presence of healthy adult participants) are satisfied based on the abstract.

The study used fMRI while participants viewed and responded to facial expressions (a social perception/understanding of others task) and includes a healthy control group with no family history of autism. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages meet 18–65 criterion.
fMRI was conducted during a mentalizing (social cognition) task (Domino task), and the study included a healthy control group of adults aged 18–34. Thus it meets both I1 and I2.

Abstract reports fMRI during self- and other-reflection (social-related processing) satisfying I1. However, it does not specify inclusion of a healthy control group (I2 uncertain). Insufficient information to determine presence of healthy adults, so include for full-text review.

Participants are adolescents with autism (children/adolescents), not healthy adults 18–65. The study uses fMRI with a social joint-attention task (I1 met), but does not include a healthy adult group aged 18–65 (I2 not met), so it does not meet the review population criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI study with adults (including healthy controls) and does not report any task-based social processing paradigm; therefore it fails inclusion criterion I1. I2 is satisfied (healthy adult control group present).

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social or task-based social processing), so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. Participants are healthy adults (I2 satisfied), but the review requires task-based fMRI of social processing. No exclusion criteria (e.g., systematic review) apply.

Abstract reports an fMRI study where participants viewed emotional facial expressions (social-emotion processing) and includes matched control group of young healthy adults. This satisfies social-related task with functional MRI and presence of a healthy adult group (likely aged 18–65).

The study used fMRI hyperscanning during joint attention tasks, a social cognitive paradigm, so I1 is satisfied. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state that participants were healthy adults (18–65), so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Per instructions, include for full-text review to verify health and age criteria.

Study participants are adolescents (typically developing adolescents) rather than healthy adults aged 18–65, so inclusion criterion I2 is not met. Although an fMRI social cognition task was used (satisfying I1), the review requires healthy adult participants. No exclusion criterion (e.g., E1) applies.

Participants are patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (a-MCI); no healthy adult (age 18–65) group is reported. Although the fMRI task involved face-name associations (social-related), the absence of healthy participants means inclusion criterion I2 is not met, so exclude.

Hyperscanning fMRI was used during a real-time joint-attention social interaction task, satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults (18–65), so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult mothers performing a social-related task (viewing own vs unfamiliar child/dog) probing affiliation/attachment and social cognition. Participants are healthy adults, matching age criteria. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion.

The study used resting-state fMRI, not a task-based social processing paradigm, so it does not meet I1. Although lean healthy controls are included (I2 satisfied), the primary imaging was not during a social-related task; not a systematic review (E1 not applicable).

Abstract describes an fMRI face-processing task involving dynamic social stimuli (meets social-related fMRI criterion I1). However, it does not state whether healthy adult controls (age 18–65) were included; insufficient information to confirm I2. Include for full-text review to determine presence of healthy participants.

Abstract reports a functional MRI study of human perception of different laughter types, a social-communication task (I1). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state the sample were healthy adults (I2 unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Functional MRI was used while participants performed a self-evaluation task (perception/understanding of self), a social-related construct. The sample includes a matched healthy control group alongside patients with schizophrenia. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study used fMRI while participants performed a social-related task (IAT with faces/names of politicians), examining perception/attitudes toward others. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Fits social processing in healthy adults (I1, I2). Not a review article.

Title and abstract describe an fMRI BOLD response to an 'eyes task' assessing theory of mind/social cognition, meeting I1. The abstract does not specify whether at least one group are healthy adults (18–65), so inclusion for full-text review is needed to determine I2.

Human fMRI study examining mirror neuron responses to hand actions and whether emotional (positive/negative/neutral) cues modulate those responses. The task probes social-cognitive processes (action/emotion perception). Participants are human adults (no clinical groups reported). Thus it meets inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

fMRI was conducted during an empathy-for-pain task (social perception/understanding of others). The study includes healthy young adults aged 20–30 (within 18–65), satisfying I1 and I2. No exclusion criteria are met.

Double-blind randomized crossover fMRI study in 18 healthy right-handed adult males performing a validated Theory of Mind social cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes), meeting social-task and healthy-adult criteria.

The study used fMRI during perception of nonverbal social signals (voice and face), which meets I1 (social-related task). The abstract implies healthy individual subjects but does not explicitly state ages or health status; given ambiguity, include for full-text review to confirm I2 (healthy adults 18–65).

The study used fMRI to examine integration of speaker characteristics with sentence content—an aspect of social communication/pragmatic processing—meeting I1. It includes matched control (healthy) adult participants, meeting I2. No exclusion criteria apply.
This fMRI study scanned healthy adult participants during a social-related task (reflection on self and mother), directly addressing social cognition. It therefore satisfies I1 and I2.

Abstract clearly reports functional MRI recorded during social interactions (dual-fMRI) involving cooperation and competition, meeting I1. The abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or that participants were healthy adults, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

Participants were adolescents (typically developing and ASD), not adults aged 18–65, so the study does not include a healthy adult group and fails inclusion criterion I2, despite using fMRI and social tasks (I1).

This study used resting-state fMRI (rs-fMRI) and reports altered default network connectivity and associations with theory-of-mind in schizophrenia; it does not report a task-based social processing fMRI paradigm (I1 not met). It is not a review/meta-analysis. Healthy control inclusion is unclear from the abstract. Exclusion based on failure to meet the task-based inclusion criterion.

This article is a review of seven structural/functional MRI studies in ADHD samples (not primary fMRI research in healthy adults) and thus meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses. It also focuses on ADHD participants rather than healthy 18–65 adults.

Study used fMRI face-processing tasks (meets I1) but participants were individuals with a psychotic disorder only (no healthy adult group reported), so it does not meet I2 (required healthy participants 18–65).

fMRI study examining mentalizing (social cognition) during tasks about self/other; includes an age- and IQ-matched healthy control group of adults. Abstract provides clear evidence meeting inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

Study used fMRI while healthy participants anticipated and interpreted others' actions (badminton stroke direction), fitting 'Perception and Understanding of Others' social processing. Participants are players of varying skill levels (presumably adults). No exclusion criteria met.
This record is a systematic review/meta-analysis protocol rather than an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults, so it meets exclusion criterion E1.

The study uses fMRI during an affective mentalizing (social) task (meets I1) but compares psychotic offenders to nonpsychotic offenders drawn from a forensic inpatient population; no group of healthy (community) participants aged 18–65 is described, so it fails inclusion criterion I2.

fMRI was conducted while participants read a suspenseful literary text and rated experienced suspense; reported activation in brain areas associated with social cognition/predictive inference (relevant to perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not state ages explicitly, but participants appear to be healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant age and health status.

The study used fMRI to measure amygdala responses to direct vs. averted gaze (a social-cognition task) in N=55 healthy adult males — satisfying I1 and I2. It is an original experimental study (not a review) and provides sufficient abstract detail for inclusion in full-text review.

fMRI study examining face encoding and recognition (perception/understanding of others), which is a social-related task; includes a healthy adult control group (21 controls). Not a review. Abstract provides clear info matching inclusion criteria.

The study used an fMRI facial emotion recognition task (I1 met) but enrolled only participants with schizophrenia randomized to training or games; no healthy adult control group (age 18–65) is reported, so I2 is not satisfied. Exclude for absence of healthy participants.

The study used fMRI during social-cognition tasks but reports only 13 PTSD patients and does not mention any healthy adult control group; therefore it fails inclusion criterion I2 (no healthy participants aged 18–65).

fMRI study examining cortical processing of vocal (socially relevant) sounds, meeting I1. Abstract does not specify whether a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) was included, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to determine presence of healthy participants and age range.

Abstract reports neural (medial prefrontal) responses to social interaction images, indicating an fMRI social-related task (I1). Although focused on remitted depression, such studies typically include a healthy comparison group; the abstract implies relevance to healthy volunteers but does not explicitly state sample details. Because it likely includes healthy adults and meets the review objective but lacks full participant detail, include for full-text review to confirm I2.

Abstract does not describe any social-related task or social processing; it analyses semi-metric properties of functional brain networks in individuals with familial risk for psychosis versus controls. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (fMRI during a social-related task). No exclusion criteria (E1) apply based on the abstract.
fMRI study where adult participants viewed dynamic emotional facial expressions (a social perception/understanding task), and includes healthy control groups. Thus meets I1 and I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of face processing (a social-related task) in adults with Asperger syndrome, meeting I1. The abstract does not state whether a healthy control group (age 18–65) was included, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Insufficient information to exclude—include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy participants.

fMRI study where participants viewed cooperative vs. noncooperative interactions (a social cognition/perception task) and includes a healthy matched control group. This meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult participants). Not a review; no exclusion criteria met.

Participants are children (boys); no healthy adult (age 18–65) group is included. Although the study uses fMRI on social/face processing (I1), it fails inclusion criterion I2 (no healthy adult participants), so it does not meet the meta-analysis population requirement.
fMRI social task is present (I1), but the healthy control group consists of adolescents (ages 12–19), not adults 18–65; thus inclusion criterion I2 is not met. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

The study uses fMRI to investigate memory-retrieval and white-matter connectivity in ventrolateral prefrontal cortex, not social-related processing. It does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (no social task). Participants are unspecified but that is moot given lack of social paradigm.

Abstract reports an fMRI investigation of social cognitive processing and compares patients with schizophrenia to their unaffected siblings, indicating presence of healthy participant group performing social-related tasks. Although ages are not specified, unaffected siblings are likely healthy adults; include for full-text confirmation.

Excluded: all participants were schizophrenia outpatients and no healthy control group (age 18–65) was included, so inclusion criterion I2 is not met. The study does meet I1 (fMRI emotion-recognition task) but lacks healthy participants.

fMRI affective ToM task is social processing (meets I1), but participants are only chronic depression patients with no healthy adult group reported (does not meet I2). Exclude based on absence of healthy participants.

The title indicates a multilevel kernel density fMRI analysis, which is a coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI experiment with participants. This meets exclusion criterion E1 (meta-analysis).

fMRI was used while participants performed prayer, which the authors frame as recruiting social-cognition areas (mPFC, TPJ, temporopolar, precuneus), satisfying I1. The sample is described as a group of Danish Christians (healthy adult participants), meeting I2 though exact ages aren’t reported; include for full-text confirmation.

The study reports an fMRI social-contingency task probing self-relevant social reward processing (meets I1) and includes a neurotypical healthy adult control group matched to the ASD group (meets I2). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing paradigm). Inclusion criterion I1 requires a task-based social-related fMRI. Participants are healthy adults (I2 met), but absence of a social task makes the study ineligible for this review.

The study used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS), not functional MRI; therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. It does include healthy adults (I2), and is not a systematic review (E1 not applicable).

Event-related fMRI using a false-belief paradigm investigated understanding others' mental states (a social cognition task). The abstract implies a sample of individual subjects with personality scores and no indication of clinical populations. Thus it meets I1 and likely I2; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.

Participants are adolescents (mean ages 15.8 and 16.2), not adults aged 18–65, so the study does not meet inclusion criterion I2. Although it uses fMRI and socioaffective cues (I1), the age criterion excludes it from this review.

Abstract does not state that functional MRI was used, nor does it specify inclusion of healthy adult participants (18–65). Because key inclusion criteria (I1, I2) cannot be confirmed from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI in first-episode schizophrenia with a healthy control group but does not clearly state that participants performed a social-related task (appears to report intrinsic/background connectivity). Insufficient information to determine whether I1 is met; healthy controls are present (I2). Include for full-text review to confirm task and adult age range.

Randomized, placebo-controlled within-subject fMRI study measuring neural and emotional responses to interpersonal social touch in 40 healthy adult males; clearly a social-related task and includes healthy participants. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses resting-state fMRI in an autism clinical context and does not report a task-based social processing paradigm in healthy adults. It therefore fails the required inclusion criteria (I1: task-based social fMRI; I2: healthy adult task group).

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition (fear recognition, theory of mind, gaze processing) in a sample of healthy adult men from the general population; fMRI contrasts and connectivity analyses are reported. This satisfies I1 and I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study during a face perception task with emotional and neutral stimuli (social-related processing) and explicitly includes a healthy control group compared with social phobia patients. Ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text should confirm 18–65, but the study meets I1 and I2 based on available information.

fMRI study of altered perception and identification with body checking targets 'Perception and Understanding of Self' (meets I1). Abstract does not specify whether a healthy adult comparison group was included (uncertain for I2), so include for full-text review to determine presence of healthy participants.

fMRI study investigating verbal irony and theory-of-mind processing—clearly a social cognition task (meets I1). Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state groups were healthy adults (I2 unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI during a social-related ‘social reflection’ task and includes 22 healthy subjects, satisfying task-based fMRI in healthy participants. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are within 18–65.

fMRI study examining perception of vocal emotions (social communication/perception of others) during task; meets social-related task criterion. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Participants are children aged 7–12; no group of healthy adults (18–65) is included, so the study does not meet inclusion criterion I2. The study does use fMRI during a social-related movie (I1 satisfied), but absence of adult participants places it outside the review scope.

Participants are described as youth/unaffected youth at familial risk and pediatric bipolar disorder—sample appears to be children/adolescents, not adults 18–65, so inclusion criterion I2 (healthy adults 18–65) is not met. Abstract does not indicate any healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., review) apply.

This study used resting-state fMRI in ultra-high-risk (UHR) subjects rather than an active social-related task, and the abstract does not indicate a healthy adult task group (18–65). It therefore fails to meet inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

Abstract explicitly states the article is a review of neuroimaging (fMRI and PET) studies rather than reporting original fMRI data from participants. This meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (E1).

Abstract describes two fMRI studies in healthy young adults using a social attribution task (perception of human-like interactions), which is a social-related task. The sample includes healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

fMRI was used while participants made charitable donation decisions (a social-related task involving altruism/moral beliefs), and the study reports healthy adult participants. Thus it satisfies I1 and I2 for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study where mothers were scanned in response to emotional expressions of their own children—a social/attachment-related task satisfying I1. Participants are adult mothers (preterm vs full-term groups) and the abstract does not indicate psychiatric/neurological disorders, satisfying I2 (healthy adult group present). Not a review. Therefore study meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports neuronal/brain activation (amygdala, STS) related to affective theory-of-mind and emotion/neutral expression processing, indicating fMRI of social-related tasks. However, it focuses on schizophrenia out-patients and does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 18–65) was included. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants.

Resting-state fMRI study; participants did not perform a social-related task during scanning, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. The sample appears to be healthy adults (I2 met), but lack of task-based social processing excludes it from this review.

Event-related fMRI was used during a gaze-processing task probing intentions/social cognition, satisfying I1. A typically developing control group is reported but participant ages are not specified, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review.

The study used event-related fMRI while participants viewed faces of political candidates—a social perception/affiliation task—and reports healthy adult participants (registered Democrats and Republicans). This satisfies social-related processing (I1) and inclusion of healthy adults (I2).

Abstract reports an fMRI study in which participants performed a virtual-reality social cognition task (attributing others' emotions) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=14), satisfying I1 and I2. No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study investigating event simulation and mentalizing-related processes (social cognition) during task performance, meeting the social-related task requirement. The abstract does not report participant ages, so I2 (age 18–65) cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify participant demographics.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than an active, social-related task, so it does not meet I1. It does include a healthy postpartum control group (I2 satisfied), but the primary inclusion requirement of task-based social processing is not met.

Abstract reports fMRI-based gaze-contingent paradigms that create interactive social stimuli, satisfying I1. Participant health status and ages (I2) are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Participants are a sample of 17 young adults with high-functioning ASD only; no group of healthy adults is reported, so the study does not meet inclusion criterion I2 (healthy participants aged 18–65).

fMRI was used during a face discrimination task (social processing). The study includes a group of age- and gender-matched healthy adults (chronological age-matched controls), satisfying requirement for healthy participants. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet I1 and I2.

The study uses resting-state fMRI (not a task-based social processing paradigm) and participants are adolescent males (not healthy adults aged 18–65). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply based on the abstract.

Although the study used fMRI to examine pragmatic/social language (meets I1), all participants were children (ASD and typically developing). No healthy adult (age 18–65) group is included, so it fails inclusion criterion I2.

fMRI was used with a social-processing task (direct vs averted gaze across emotions), and the study includes a healthy comparison group (16 healthy adults). Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during an affect-matching task with fearful and angry faces (social cue processing), and included a healthy comparison group. Thus it meets the review’s social-processing task requirement and contains at least one healthy adult group suitable for inclusion.

The study used fMRI while participants made emotion (social) and age judgments of faces (social perception of others), and included a healthy community control group of adults. It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Participants are children (children with ASD, unaffected siblings, and matched control children), not healthy adults 18–65, so the study fails inclusion criterion I2. The study does involve an fMRI social task (I1), but the age criterion for the meta-analysis is not met. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of promotion/prevention goal activation and self-regulation; task involves social-cognitive processing of personal goals (perception/understanding of self). Sixteen participants underwent fMRI with no clinical populations mentioned. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.

The study used fMRI during a social-related task (direct vs averted gaze) and included a healthy control group (16 healthy subjects). Age range not specified in abstract, but participants are described as adults; include for full-text to confirm ages and extract data.

fMRI was used to examine neural responses to emotional facial expressions (a social-related task), satisfying I1. The abstract reports WS and control groups, but does not specify that controls are healthy adults aged 18–65, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to verify participant age/health criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of emotional face viewing (social perception), meeting I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract. No exclusion criteria apply. Include for full-text review to verify participant health/age and other details.

fMRI was used while healthy subjects viewed humorous vs non-humorous cartoons—a task tapping humor/social communication processing, relevant to social-related processing. Abstract confirms healthy adult participants but does not report ages; include for full-text review to verify age range, sample details, and methods.

fMRI study investigating memory for emotional (angry) faces—this is social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not state participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (I2). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Participants are adolescents ('youth'), not adults 18–65, so the study does not meet inclusion criterion I2 (requires healthy participants age 18–65). Although it appears to involve social processing and likely fMRI (VLPFC), the age criterion is not met based on the abstract.

fMRI study measuring mirror neuron system responses during observation of goal-directed hand actions (a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others). Includes a non-alexithymic control group (healthy adults) alongside alexithymic participants. Satisfies I1 and I2.

Abstract reports event-related fMRI during perception of intentional agency from animated shapes, a social-processing task (meets I1). Participant health status and ages (18–65) are not specified in the abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

The abstract reports an fMRI study of perception of biological motion, which is a social-cognition-related task (meets I1). The abstract does not state whether healthy adult participants (age 18–65) were included, so inclusion criterion I2 is unclear; include for full-text review to confirm participant groups.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining vicarious somatosensory responses during observation of touch (a social-perception task related to perception/understanding of others) and links results to empathy traits. Although ages/health status are not explicitly stated, no patient groups are mentioned; study likely used healthy adult participants. Include for full-text to confirm sample details.

Abstract explicitly states this is a selective review rather than an original fMRI study. It does not report primary fMRI data on social tasks in healthy adults, so it meets exclusion criterion E1 (review/meta-analysis).

fMRI study where participants observed others’ pain (social perception/understanding of others), and healthy controls are reported (controls compared to patients). Thus it meets I1 and I2 for inclusion.

Abstract is too brief to confirm whether fMRI was conducted during a social-related task or whether healthy adult participants (18–65) were included. No exclusion criteria apply. Include for full-text review to determine I1 and I2.

The study used functional MRI during a social task (modified prisoner’s dilemma) investigating Theory of Mind/representation of others and reports data from healthy control participants (n=20) alongside patients. This satisfies I1 and I2. Not a review/meta-analysis.
