Study reports fMRI during a standardized facial emotion recognition task (social communication/perception) in a sample of healthy subjects, meeting both criteria for social-related task and healthy adult participants. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study of social processing (gaze direction) meeting I1. The study includes a typically developing (healthy) comparison group, suggesting I2, though exact ages are not specified; include for full-text review to confirm adult age range.

fMRI study examining perception of self and others (body perception), a social-related task—meets I1. Abstract reports healthy participants but does not state ages (18–65), so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review to verify age eligibility.

The abstract reports an fMRI study investigating processing of goal-directed actions and inference of others' intentions, which fits social perception/understanding (I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so inclusion criterion I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify.

fMRI was used to measure brain activity during perception of emotional gestures, which is a social-related task (I1). The abstract mentions control participants (healthy), but ages (18–65) are not specified. Insufficient age information; include for full-text review to confirm I2.

Abstract indicates this article is a narrative review of the field (a review of major steps over 3 decades), not an original fMRI study with healthy participants. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (E1).
Abstract explicitly states this is a systematic review/meta-analysis of neuroimaging studies rather than primary fMRI research with participants, so it meets exclusion criterion E1.

This paper is explicitly a systematic review of published neuroscience studies on mirror neurons in autism (title and abstract state it is a systematic review). It is not an original fMRI study of healthy adults, so it meets exclusion criterion E1.

The study used fMRI during a social task (I1 satisfied) but all participants were adolescents (ages 12–18). There is no group of healthy adults aged 18–65, so inclusion criterion I2 is not met. Therefore the study does not match the review’s population.

Abstract describes a review article summarizing neurobiological findings in patients with bipolar disorder rather than reporting a primary fMRI study in healthy adults. It is a secondary review (not original fMRI data) and focuses on patient groups, so exclude.

Abstract describes an fMRI paradigm probing maternal responses to child affect (a social-related task), satisfying I1. However, it does not clearly state inclusion of any healthy adult participants aged 18–65 (appears focused on depressed mothers), so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to determine participant health status.

Abstract reports fMRI functional connectivity during emotional processing in a sample of 14 females with borderline personality disorder; no healthy control group or adults without psychiatric disorder are mentioned, so inclusion criterion I2 (at least one healthy participant group aged 18–65) is not met. Although the task relates to social/emotional processing (I1), lack of healthy participants warrants exclusion for this review.

Abstract reports fMRI during a facial imitate/observe task (social processing) and includes people with and without severe mental illness, implying a healthy control group; not a review. Satisfies social-task fMRI and presence of healthy adult participants.

Study examines cognitive deficits in schizophrenia using the MCCB and multimodal imaging in patients, not fMRI of social-related tasks in healthy adults. Does not meet I1 (no social task reported) or I2 (focus on schizophrenia patients rather than healthy 18–65 group).

This is a narrative review of magnetoencephalography (MEG), not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults; does not meet inclusion criteria. It is a review article and not relevant to the meta-analysis objective.

This article is a quantitative meta-analysis of fMRI studies (not a primary fMRI study). Exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses) applies, so it should be excluded despite addressing social/pragmatic language processing in healthy adults.

Study used fMRI during a naturalistic social task (watching sitcom with socially awkward moments) and included a healthy control group, addressing social processing. Age range (18–65) not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

Event-related fMRI examined evaluative judgments linked to self-referential processing/theory of mind (a social-related task), and the study included age-matched healthy control subjects (young adults). Thus it meets the fMRI social-task criterion and includes healthy participants.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. Although healthy controls were included (I2), the absence of a social-related task makes it ineligible for this review.

fMRI data were acquired while participants played multiple-round trust games (a social interaction/reward task), satisfying I1. The study includes a healthy control group (n=20), satisfying I2. No exclusion criteria are met in the abstract.

Participants are adolescents (study repeatedly states ‘adolescents’), not adults aged 18–65. Although an fMRI social-evaluation task was used (I1) and a healthy control group was included, the sample does not meet the required adult age range (I2), so the study is not eligible for this review.

The study used resting-state fMRI after cTBS rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (task-based social processing). No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply based on the abstract.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task), so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. The abstract includes healthy controls but does not report ages to confirm I2. No exclusion criteria (e.g., reviews) apply.

fMRI responses were measured during passive viewing of natural movies and analyses report voxel tuning differences to a 'social communication' category, indicating social-related processing. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm I2.

Abstract reports fMRI assessment of amygdala responsiveness to social-phobia-related verbal stimuli (meets I1). Study includes 110 matched healthy control participants alongside patients with SAD (meets I2). Not a review/meta-analysis. Sufficient abstract information to include for full review.

The study focuses on pediatric/youth populations (high-risk and bipolar youth), not healthy adults aged 18–65, and therefore does not meet inclusion criterion I2. The abstract also does not describe fMRI of social-processing in healthy adult participants.
The study is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis (systematic review/meta-analysis), which meets exclusion criterion E1.

Abstract reports an fMRI task probing simulation of others' painful experiences (a social-related process) and includes a psychiatrically-healthy control group. Age range not reported in abstract; include for full-text verification of ages.

The study used fMRI in healthy adult participants (18 male non-musicians) but the task is an aesthetic music-rating task, not explicitly described as a social-related task. However, the abstract reports activation of ToM/social-cognition areas (PCC/PC, arMFC, TPJ) suggesting social-related processing may be involved. Because the abstract is ambiguous about whether the task was social, include for full-text review.

Participants are children (typically developing and ASD children), not healthy adults aged 18–65, so inclusion criterion I2 is not met. The study does use fMRI in a social face-processing task (I1), but the age range excludes it from this review.

Abstract does not specify whether fMRI was performed during a social-related task or whether a healthy control group (age 18–65) was included. The study involves oxytocin in adults with autism but provides insufficient details to determine eligibility — include for full-text review.

Abstract describes a narrative review/synthesis of mirror neuron findings and introduces a special issue; it does not report original fMRI data or participant samples. This meets exclusion criterion E1 (review/meta-analysis).

Title indicates an fMRI study of deception (a social-cognitive process), suggesting I1 may be met. However the abstract provides no details on participant groups or ages, so presence of healthy adults (I2) is unclear. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria fully — include for full-text review.

fMRI was used during facial emotion processing (social cognition/perception of others), and the study includes a normal control user group (healthy adults). Thus it meets I1 and I2 and is relevant to social-related processing in healthy adults.

Abstract describes a methodological tutorial on intersubject correlation without reporting an empirical fMRI experiment, participant ages, or social task details. Information is insufficient to confirm I1 or I2. Include for full-text review to determine whether empirical data meeting inclusion criteria are reported.

This is a structural MRI volumetric study (manual tracing of fusiform gyrus) in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome and controls, not a task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It therefore fails I1 (no fMRI social task) and does not meet the review objective.

Does not report an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults; this is a narrative review proposing BLA deep brain stimulation for severe autism and discusses pathophysiology and a case report. No fMRI task data or healthy adult participant group is described in the abstract.

Participants are adolescents (ages 11.1–15.5), not adults 18–65 required by inclusion criterion I2. The study did use fMRI and a social task (I1 satisfied) but fails the age criterion, so exclude based on population.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of recognition of happy faces (a social cognition task), satisfying I1. It does not specify whether healthy control participants (age 18–65) were included, so eligibility for I2 is unclear. Per screening rules, include for full-text review to determine presence of healthy participants.

The abstract indicates this is a literature review of atypical hemispheric specialization in motor domain in ASD, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

The study reports functional MRI during a scanner-adapted Multifaceted Empathy Test assessing social cognition/empathy (meets I1). It includes 50 age- and gender-matched healthy control participants alongside patients (meets I2). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Study uses fMRI with a social task (Cyberball) but samples adolescents (including healthy adolescents), not adults aged 18–65. Thus it does not meet inclusion criterion I2 (healthy participants age 18–65).

Abstract text is insufficient to confirm whether an fMRI social-processing task was used or whether a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) was included. The title and summary reference neural correlates/reward and social interaction in autism, suggesting a possible fMRI study with relevance to social reward, so include for full-text review to determine I1 and I2.

fMRI was used while participants processed idiographic negative self-beliefs (self-related processing) and implemented regulation strategies; sample consisted of healthy adults (35, right-handed). Meets both inclusion criteria.

The study examines facial emotion processing (a social-related task) and reports neurofunctional comparisons between first-episode psychosis patients and healthy subjects, indicating it likely used functional neuroimaging and includes a healthy adult group. The abstract lacks explicit mention of fMRI and participant ages, so full-text review is needed to confirm; therefore include for further assessment.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining personal space/affiliation (social vs non-social stimuli) with imaging results; meets I1. The abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone—include for full-text review.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing), so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (fMRI during a social-related task). Although healthy controls are included, absence of a social task makes it ineligible for this review.

fMRI study where participants viewed social (faces, people) vs nonsocial images, directly addressing social perception (I1). The sample includes a healthy comparison group (n=14), meeting the requirement for healthy adults (I2); ages not stated in abstract, so full text should confirm age range. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and extract data.

Abstract reports fMRI measuring amygdala and fusiform responses to neutral faces during attention tasks, which is social-related processing (satisfies I1). However, participants are described as a chronic traumatic brain injury population with no clear mention of healthy control group (I2 unclear). Include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults.

fMRI study with normal volunteers performing tasks to identify and attribute observed emotional behavior—social perception and understanding of others. Participants are described as normal volunteers (healthy adults). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion.

This article is a narrative review of the neurobiology of social phobia, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It explicitly states it is a review, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (E1).

This is an fMRI study probing social-cognitive processing (responses to narratives appealing to protected values), which satisfies I1. The abstract reports 78 adult participants from multiple countries but does not specify ages or explicit healthy status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone; full-text review is needed to verify eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social decision-making from faces (social cognition/empathy) comparing males and females and including individuals with ASD; includes healthy adult groups. This satisfies social-related fMRI task (I1) and presence of healthy adult participants (I2). Not a review.

Participants are early adolescent girls (minors); no group of healthy adults aged 18–65 is reported, so the study fails inclusion criterion I2 (age). The study does use fMRI for a social task (I1 met) but absence of adult participants excludes it from this review.

Study involves fMRI in patients with mild traumatic brain injury undergoing piano-based cognitive rehabilitation; no evidence of a social-related task or involvement of healthy adult participants (18–65). Not a systematic review. Does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

This article is a narrative review of neuroimaging in autism (not a primary fMRI study). It clearly states it is reviewing current knowledge, meeting exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews/meta-analyses). Abstract lacks data on fMRI in healthy adults performing social tasks.

Abstract reports event-related fMRI during implicit facial emotion processing, which is a social-related task (meets I1). The abstract does not state whether a healthy control group aged 18–65 was included (I2 cannot be confirmed). Include for full-text review to determine presence of healthy adult participants.

Participants are young children with ASD (case studies), not healthy adults (age 18–65). Although fMRI of social stimuli was used, the sample does not include a healthy adult group, so it does not meet the population criterion.

fMRI study examining second-language communicative speech (social communication) in healthy adult native Japanese speakers; neural correlates of social interaction/communication were measured during task-based fMRI. This directly meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult participants). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants to investigate social-cognitive processing (third-party punishment, mentalizing and understanding others) and reports neural connectivity related to social judgment, meeting both criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This fMRI study measured neural activation while participants judged faces as trustworthy/untrustworthy (a social cognition task) and included a healthy control group. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants were aged 18–65.

fMRI was used to measure empathic responses in an 'empathy for pain' social task (social processing). The study included both autistic and control participants (healthy adult controls), satisfying inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

The study uses fMRI of social stimuli but participants are children aged 7–13 (autism and typically developing), not healthy adults 18–65 required by I2. Therefore it does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion for the review.

fMRI study where participants used Compassion-meditation or Reappraisal while viewing film clips of people in distress—a social-affective task (perception/understanding of others; affiliation).
