The abstract describes simultaneous fMRI-PET probing mothers' neural responses to their infants and connectivity in a social-affiliation/attachment network, indicating an fMRI social task (I1). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy status, so full text is needed to confirm I2; therefore include for full-text review.
fMRI study using a social interaction task (virtual ball-tossing/exclusion) with a healthy control group reported; meets criteria for social-related processing and includes healthy adults.

Abstract describes brain imaging of theory of mind and empathy in schizophrenia but does not specify whether this study used task-based fMRI during social tasks or included a healthy adult control group. Insufficient information to determine I1 and I2 from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants performed audiovisual speech perception, which qualifies as social communication (social-related). The study includes a healthy, age-matched control group of adults. No exclusion criteria are met.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a Theory of Mind task (social cognition) and includes a healthy adult control group (25 age- and gender-matched controls). Although it also includes a Tourette syndrome group, inclusion criteria allow studies with additional clinical groups as long as healthy adults (18–65) are present.

This is an editorial/introduction to a special issue, not a primary empirical fMRI study. The abstract does not report an fMRI experiment with human participants performing a social task and thus does not meet inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

fMRI study examining social cue (fearful gaze) processing using real face stimuli; includes a matched healthy adult control group. Meets I1 (task-based fMRI of social processing) and I2 (healthy adult controls).

Abstract indicates this is an overview/review of molecular neuroimaging studies, not an original fMRI study with participants performing a social task. This meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review/meta-analysis).

Abstract reports functional MRI hemodynamic responses to child stimuli (social-cognition related) in human mothers, indicating a social-related task during fMRI (I1). The participants are adult humans (maternal parenting), fitting the healthy adult group criterion (I2). Not a review. Sufficient information in abstract to include for full-text review.

Abstract describes a conceptual primer/review of brain-imaging principles, not an empirical fMRI study with participants performing a social task. No methods or participant data reported; does not meet inclusion criteria I1/I2.

Abstract appears to be a narrative review summarizing fMRI, TMS, and EEG findings in ASD rather than reporting a primary fMRI study in healthy adults. No methods or participant details given, and no confirmation of healthy adult fMRI data. Insufficient information to determine inclusion; include for full-text review.

The study investigates executive dysfunction in autism spectrum disorder using fMRI and network hub architecture, not social-related processing. It focuses on ASD (clinical population) rather than fMRI of social tasks in healthy adults, so it does not meet the review inclusion criteria.

The fMRI task involves vocal imitation/speech repetition, which the authors describe as an element of social communication, and the study includes healthy younger and older participants. Abstract lacks full details on participant ages and whether the task was explicitly social, so full-text review is warranted.

fMRI study investigating theory of mind (social cognition) using intention conditions; includes healthy control group (controls) allowing extraction of healthy adult data. Fits social-related processing in humans and includes at least one healthy participant group.

This fMRI study examines attentional orienting using gaze cues, a social-related process (perception/understanding of others), satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit health status, so I2 is unclear — include for full-text review to confirm.

Task-based fMRI study investigating gaze (direct vs averted) — a social signal — during an action-control task in 30 healthy participants. Abstract confirms fMRI of social processing and healthy sample; ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm age criterion.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI during social cognition tasks (eye gaze, face processing, theory-of-mind, action understanding) and includes neurotypical control participants. Thus it meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (presence of healthy participants). No exclusion criteria apply.

Study reports fMRI with multivariate decoding during altruistic/prosocial choice tasks (social processing). Abstract implies human participants and focuses on prosocial attributes, meeting social-related task criterion. Demographics/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation of healthy adult sample.

Abstract reports an fMRI social approval task (social reward processing) and includes a healthy control group. Age range not provided in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–65 criterion and extract required details.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment manipulating beliefs about human vs robot agents and examines person perception and mentalizing networks (social cognition). Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

Study participants are children (ASD and typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 18–65 required by I2; therefore it does not meet the population inclusion criterion. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants that manipulated communicative (social communication) versus descriptive speech, directly investigating neural correlates of social communication and effects of anxiety/proficiency. It meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adults).

The abstract describes an fMRI study examining social cognition (theory of mind, action understanding, mirror neuron system) and includes a healthy control group alongside ALS patients. This meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy participants present). No exclusion criteria are met.

The study used resting-state fMRI, not a task-based social-processing fMRI paradigm, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. Although healthy controls are included (I2), the primary fMRI data are not from a social task.

The study used structural MRI covariance analysis rather than functional MRI during a social task, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. The abstract indicates healthy control participants were included (I2).

Resting-state fMRI in a sample of 74 MDD patients; no task-based social processing paradigm reported and no healthy participant group (age 18–65) included. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

The study participants are boys (children/adolescents), not healthy adults aged 18–65 (fails I2). The imaging was resting-state and structural connectivity analysis, not an fMRI social-related task (fails I1). Therefore it does not meet the review inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in humans examining representation/understanding of others' actions (mirror system), which maps to social perception/understanding—meets I1. Abstract indicates human participants but does not specify ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so I2 cannot be fully confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review to verify participant ages/health.

fMRI study in healthy adult subject groups observing an expert demonstrator; explicitly investigates social-cognition mechanisms (motor resonance, mentalizing, recognition of intentions), which are social-related processes. Abstract implies healthy Naïve/Trained/Expert participants though ages not specified—full text can confirm. No exclusion criteria met.

The article appears to be a review of neuroimaging literature (published in 'Sexual Medicine Reviews') rather than an original fMRI study on social processing. It summarizes findings and limitations across studies, meeting exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review/meta-analysis/narrative review).

The study is an fMRI investigation of memory control and recognition processes, not social-related processing. The abstract contains no social tasks or constructs (affiliation, social communication, perception of self/others). It therefore does not meet the review objective.

Abstract reports neural responses (ventral tegmental area, amygdala) during the Prisoner’s Dilemma social interaction task and refers to 'scan', indicating functional neuroimaging during a social task (satisfies I1). Participant health status and ages are not explicitly stated, so I2 is unclear; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI examining amygdala connectivity during an emotional task (relevant to social/emotional processing) and includes a healthy control group. Age range not specified in abstract, but presence of healthy controls and social-cognition implications warrant full-text review to confirm adult (18–65) status and task details.

fMRI study of emotional reactions during social decision-making (social scenarios). Includes a young adult healthy participant group (meets age 18–65 requirement). No exclusion criteria met in abstract.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of prosodic speech (a social-communication-related construct) but does not report whether a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm I2, so include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI to investigate action recognition in brain regions, which maps onto social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult status, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm I2.

While the study uses fMRI for a social moral judgment task (I1 satisfied), all participants are children (including autistic and ‘normal’ children). No healthy adult (age 18–65) group is included, so I2 is not met. Exclude on that basis.

Abstract describes an fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating perception of social stimuli (spatial relations between bodies facing vs nonfacing), meeting the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining memory for neutral faces in goal-relevant vs goal-irrelevant situations; reports social processing brain regions (superior temporal sulcus) during recognition, indicating social-related processing. Abstract implies healthy human participants (typical in such fMRI studies); include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status if needed.

The study used resting-state fMRI correlated with Theory of Mind test scores rather than a task-based fMRI scan performed during a social-related task (I1 not met). It does include a healthy control group (I2 met). No exclusion criteria (e.g., review) apply.

Sample consists of youth (children/adolescents) not adults; thus the study does not include healthy participants aged 18–65 (fails I2). The task is social-related fMRI (I1 met), but participant age criterion is not met. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

fMRI was used while participants processed emotional facial expressions (social-related task: perception/understanding of others), and the study includes a healthy control group (mean age 27, within 18–65). Not a review, so inclusion criteria I1 and I2 are satisfied.

fMRI was used while participants (congenitally blind and sighted adults) performed identity and emotion recognition from voices — a social perception task (perception/understanding of others). At least one healthy adult group (sighted) is included. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract addresses imaging of self- and other-processing (social cognition) which maps to a social-related task, but it does not specify that fMRI was used or whether a healthy adult control group (18–65) was included. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm I2 or fMRI modality—include for full-text review.

This is an fMRI study where participants generated alternative appraisals for anger-evoking events (affective creativity), engaging default-mode/social cognition networks. It appears to probe social-emotional processing and reports healthy participants, though ages are not specified. Include for full-text review to confirm task socialness and age range.

fMRI study investigating social communication (‘vitality forms’) in speech and action, meeting I1. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

fMRI study examines observation and mental imagery of face and limb movements, addressing social communication and perception of others (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

This is an fMRI study examining social processes (pupil mimicry, trust, theory-of-mind network), meeting I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state that participants were healthy adults (18–65), so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to verify participant health status and ages.

Abstract states this article 'summarizes psychopharmacological and fMRI research' — it is a review article rather than an original fMRI study. This meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses).

The study used fMRI while participants played the Trust Game (a social dilemma), addressing social-related processing. Participants are described as human Machiavellian individuals (adult sample inferred), indicating healthy adult group presence. Therefore it meets I1 and I2.

Abstract describes a review/perspective on the field of social neuroscience rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment with human participants performing social tasks. It does not report methods or participants and fits exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews/meta-analyses/perspectives).

The study used fMRI during a social appraisal task (judging emotional faces), which probes social perception/understanding of others (I1). It includes a healthy control group (n=21) alongside psychosis patients, satisfying the requirement for healthy adult participants (I2). Age range not specified in abstract—verify in full text if needed.

Abstract reports functional MRI during participants’ evaluation of body odour peptides (self vs non-self), a social-related perception/communication task (mate-choice/self-perception). Participants are described as volunteers (healthy adults). Age range not specified but sufficient evidence of fMRI in healthy human volunteers performing social-related tasks to warrant inclusion for full-text review.
Resting-state fMRI in young children (ages 3–7), not an fMRI task in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria I1 (no social-related task) or I2 (healthy adults aged 18–65).

fMRI study using a social provocation/reactive-aggression task involving opponents, probing social processing (decision about punishing others and outcome). No indication it is a review and likely uses healthy adult participants; include for full-text to confirm demographics and ages.

Abstract reports an fMRI study on hypnotic suggestion (a social influence factor) in human participants; unclear whether the task meets the review's definition of ‘social-related processing’ and exact participant ages/health are not fully specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Human fMRI study examining how learning about another person's values alters value representations and preferences (social influence). Abstract indicates an fMRI social-related task and behavioral preference shifts. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, but criteria allow inclusion if at least one healthy adult group is present; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

This study reports resting-state fMRI in patients with behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia, not task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. It does not meet inclusion criteria I1 (social-related task fMRI) or I2 (healthy adult group).

Study reports an fMRI paradigm measuring brain responses to fearful faces (a social perception task) and includes adult male control participants matched for age/IQ, satisfying presence of healthy adults. Therefore it meets social-related fMRI (I1) and includes a healthy adult group (I2).

Abstract examines neural responses to emotionally salient expressions of human eyes in adults with Tourette syndrome compared to healthy controls (a social cognition task), indicating inclusion of healthy adult participants. However, the abstract does not explicitly state that functional MRI was used. Insufficient imaging-method detail—include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and ages.

This is an RCT study protocol of a kickboxing-based training for individuals with psychotic disorders; the abstract does not mention any functional MRI, neuroimaging, or social-processing fMRI tasks, and the participants are patients rather than healthy adults (18–65). It therefore does not meet I1 or I2.

Abstract describes fMRI work on social perception in typically developing adults and reports biological-motion studies; however it is presented as a review, so it is unclear whether original fMRI data in healthy adults are reported. Include for full-text review to confirm I1 and I2.

fMRI study investigating control of shared representations and social cognition (imitation inhibition, self-other distinction, mental state attribution) — meets I1. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adults (18–65), so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

This is a narrative/review chapter appraising evidence (postmortem, structural MRI, fMRI) across neurodevelopmental disorders rather than an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

The study reports resting-state fMRI in cocaine-dependent individuals and examines decision-making/learning, not social-related processing. The abstract does not report a healthy adult group (18–65). It therefore does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. It does include healthy adults (I2), but absence of a social task makes it irrelevant to the review objective.

Abstract reports fMRI in patients with schizophrenia during a language/semantic task (not social processing) and appears to include only patients (no healthy adult group). Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 (social-related task) or I2 (healthy participants).

Participants were recruited while entering psychotherapy for depression and/or anxiety; abstract gives no indication of a healthy adult (18–65) group. Although an fMRI social task was used (I1), the study does not meet inclusion criterion I2 (healthy participants).

fMRI study examining gesture-speech integration (social communication), includes healthy participant groups (replication in healthy subjects and matched healthy controls). Abstract indicates social-related task and presence of healthy adults; age range not specified in abstract but criterion I2 satisfied by inclusion of healthy groups. No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract reports fMRI mega-analysis in which participants considered others’ mental states (social cognition), meeting I1. The abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be fully confirmed from the abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify participant age/health.
This article is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies (activation likelihood estimation of 125 papers), i.e., a systematic review/meta-analysis, which meets exclusion criterion E1.

This fMRI study investigates emotional memory (repetition suppression/enhancement for negative/positive/neutral stimuli) rather than social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception/understanding of self or others). It does not meet the review’s social-processing inclusion criterion (I1).

The study used fMRI during active listening to human footsteps, implicating the posterior superior temporal sulcus ('social cognition' area), consistent with social-related auditory processing (I1). However, the abstract does not report participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify participant details.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. It does include healthy control participants (I2 likely satisfied). No exclusion criteria (e.g., systematic review) apply. Exclude based on not addressing the task-based fMRI requirement of the review.

The study used fMRI during a Theory of Mind (social) task (I1) and includes a matched healthy control group (n=13), satisfying adult healthy participant criterion (I2). Not a review; abstract gives sufficient detail for inclusion.

Abstract reports fMRI but tasks (verbal fluency and nonsense sentence completion) are language/executive, not clearly social-related. Participants described are individuals with PAX6 mutation; no mention of a healthy adult control group. Abstract provides insufficient information to confirm social-processing task and presence of healthy adults—include for full-text review.

Participants are children with autism spectrum disorder; no healthy adult (age 18–65) group is reported. Thus the study does not meet the review’s required population (I2), although it does use fMRI with a social reward task (I1).

Participants are preschool-aged children with ASD (not healthy adults). The study appears to use functional connectivity measures rather than an fMRI social task, so it does not meet I1 or I2. No exclusion criteria (e.g., systematic review) apply.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (emotional speech prosody) examining neural responses; twenty-two adults participated and no clinical/disorder sample is reported, implying a healthy adult sample. Thus it meets I1 (social-related task) and I2 (healthy participants aged within adult range).

fMRI study of perception/understanding of others (facial expressions of disgust), meeting social-related task criterion (I1). Participants appear to be human healthy adults though ages not specified; nothing indicates patient groups only, so include for full-text to confirm demographics (I2).

The study used fMRI during a facial emotion recognition task (a social cognition task) and included a neurotypical adult control group alongside adults with Asperger syndrome, meeting both criteria. The abstract provides clear evidence of task-based fMRI in adults and presence of healthy participants.

Task-based fMRI study using an audio-visual social-norm inference task assessing social understanding in adults; includes a matched typically developing (healthy) control group. Fits I1 (social-related task during fMRI) and I2 (healthy adult participants).

This study used resting-state fMRI to parcellate lateral frontal cortex and characterize functional connectivity; it does not describe a task-based fMRI involving social-related processing. Therefore it fails inclusion criterion I1. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply based on the abstract.

Abstract addresses visual personal familiarity in amnestic MCI but does not specify that functional MRI was used nor whether a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm I1 and I2 from the abstract, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study measuring brain activity while participants observed others' actions (social cognition task), satisfying I1. Sample of 29 participants with no indication of clinical populations or minors, satisfying I2. Not a review article.
This paper is a narrative review of neuroimaging literature on face processing in ASD, not an original fMRI study with human participants; therefore it meets the review exclusion criterion.

fMRI was conducted while participants judged computer-animated characters' actions, a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state 'healthy adults', so full-text is needed to confirm I2.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed tasks including a social manipulation (peer observation) affecting social cognition processes; sample is young adults (healthy) meeting adult age range. Abstract clearly reports original empirical fMRI data rather than a review.

Abstract examines social-cognitive brain function during visual perspective-taking (relevant), but it does not explicitly state that fMRI was used nor whether a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm I1 and I2, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study administering a social cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) and includes an age-matched healthy control group. These meet I1 and I2. Not a review/meta-analysis and no exclusion criteria met in the abstract.

Study does not meet inclusion criteria: participants are children (not adults 18–65) and the fMRI data are resting-state (language network) rather than an fMRI social-related task. Therefore it is not relevant to fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.
Participants are children/adolescents (not age 18–65) and the task is basic auditory/visual perception rather than social processing; inclusion criteria I1 and I2 are not met.
This paper is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis of fMRI studies (i.e., a meta-analysis/systematic review), thus meeting exclusion criterion E1.

This article is a quantitative meta-analysis combining fMRI and PET studies (not an original fMRI experiment). Per exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses), it should be excluded despite studying social-related processes in healthy adults.

The study used fMRI while participants performed an adapted Reading-the-Mind-in-the-Eyes Task (a social cognition task) and included a non-offender healthy control group (H). Participants are adult men. Thus it meets I1 and I2.
This paper is a meta-analysis of over 200 fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI experiment; it meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses).

Abstract reports fMRI activation during processing of human action descriptions, which likely maps onto social cognition (understanding others), but it does not specify participant ages or explicitly state the task is social. Insufficient detail to be certain, so include for full-text review.

Abstract reads as a conceptual/neuroanatomical review discussing lesion and fMRI literature rather than reporting an original fMRI study. It does not state that an fMRI scan was conducted on healthy adult participants during a social task. This meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review/meta-analysis/review).

This record is a review of research (review article) on perceptual organization in schizophrenia, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

This is an fMRI study examining preconscious processing of social threat cues (fearful eyes), which fits social perception/understanding (I1). Although the abstract does not explicitly state participant health or ages, it describes a pharmacological double-blind study without mention of clinical populations, so it likely included healthy adults (I2). Include for full-text review to confirm participant details.

This study used structural MRI (cortical thickness and structural covariance) in ASD vs controls, not functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults. It does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (fMRI social task); although controls are present, the study population and methods do not match the review objective.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult groups (omnivores, vegetarians, vegans) performing an observation task of mouth actions that probes social cognition/mirror-neuron processes (perception/understanding of others). While exact ages are not reported in the abstract, participant groups are healthy adults and the study directly addresses social-related processing, so it should be included for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study probing neural mechanisms of persuasion/social influence (expert effect) on memory and attitudes, which is social-related processing. Although participant ages/health status are not explicitly stated, this appears to be a human fMRI study with healthy adult subjects; given uncertainty about demographics, include for full-text review.

The study used task-based fMRI contrasting anticipation of touching an animate (human hand) versus inanimate target, addressing social-related processing, and was conducted in healthy volunteers. It meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult participants). Not a review article. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

This paper is an activation likelihood estimation (ALE) meta-analysis synthesizing results from 16 fMRI studies rather than reporting original fMRI data collected from participants. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (E1).

This study used image-guided repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) to create a virtual lesion; no functional MRI scan was conducted. The review requires fMRI studies (I1), which is not met. Participant health/age not clearly reported, so I2 cannot be confirmed. Exclude based on not meeting I1.

Abstract reports fMRI studies of emotion perception (a social-related task) using dynamic audio-visual stimuli, satisfying I1. Participant health status and ages (I2) are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm I2.

This study used resting-state functional connectivity in adults with autism spectrum disorder and reports cerebellar morphometry and connectivity; it does not describe a task-based fMRI of social processing nor report a healthy adult task group. Therefore it does not meet the review's inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study testing effects of intranasal oxytocin on interpersonal space (a social processing task) in a double-blind placebo-controlled design with human participants; healthy adult sample implied—meets I1 and I2.

The study used fMRI during a vocal emotion recognition task, a social-processing paradigm (I1 satisfied). Participants were healthy but aged 8–19; the abstract does not confirm a distinct adult (18–65) group (I2 unclear). Because adult-group eligibility cannot be determined from the abstract, include for full-text review to verify I2.

fMRI study examining social judgments of people (perception/understanding of others), satisfying I1. The abstract does not report participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to verify that participants are healthy adults (18–65).

fMRI study with healthy adult volunteers performing judgments of pride (a self-conscious social emotion) and joy, directly assessing social-related processing. Meets criteria for social task and healthy participants; not a review.

Abstract does not specify that functional MRI was used or the ages of participants. Title suggests amygdala/mentalising in typical development and ASD (likely includes healthy participants), but information is insufficient to confirm I1 and I2 from the abstract alone; include for full-text review.

Abstract does not specify use of fMRI nor whether a healthy control group (age 18–65) was included; therefore insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone. Include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants viewed emotional faces (a social-related task: perception/understanding of others). The study includes a healthy control group. Age range not reported in abstract, so full-text review recommended to confirm 18–65 criterion.
Participants are 10–15-year-old children (not healthy adults 18–65), and the fMRI task assessed passive auditory change detection (non-social). Thus the study fails inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

fMRI study modeling neural responses to sentence content; authors identify a ‘social interaction’ factor, indicating social-related processing during the scanned task. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Participants are Latin-American preadolescents (children/adolescents), not adults aged 18–65; therefore the study does not meet inclusion criterion I2 despite meeting I1 (fMRI social task). No exclusion-by-type criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

Abstract describes developmental changes across age and face specialization but does not state fMRI use or that participants are healthy adults (18–65). Insufficient information to confirm fMRI and adult sample; include for full-text review.

fMRI study of emotional face processing during a gender discrimination task (social perception of others) in human participants; fits I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult participants). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, so it does not meet I1. Although it includes healthy adult cohorts, the absence of a social-related task means it does not fit the review’s inclusion requirements.

Event-related fMRI was used to examine how the ACC processes outcomes of others' decisions, which is a social cognition task and meets I1. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (I2 unclear). No exclusion criteria apply. Include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics and age range.

fMRI data were collected while participants viewed and recognized faces (a social perception/understanding of others task), satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study investigating agency inferences (perception/understanding of self), which is a social-related process. Includes 31 healthy control participants alongside patients. Ages not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

Event-related fMRI examined processing of emotion words (social/emotional language), which maps onto social-related processing. The study includes typically-developing control participants (healthy group), though ages are not specified in the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

Participants are adolescents (follow-up from primary-school cohort), not adults aged 18–65, so inclusion criterion I2 (≥1 healthy adult group 18–65) is not met. The study does use an fMRI social (ToM) task (I1 met) but fails the age requirement for this review.

fMRI study examining face perception and changeable aspects (expressions/viewpoint) addresses social-related processes (social communication; perception of others). Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

fMRI study of social processing (intentional causal attribution/Theory of Mind) using comic vignettes; includes participants with ASD and reports group differences, implying a healthy control group. Meets I1 and likely I2; abstract provides sufficient relevance to include for full-text verification.

The study's fMRI tasks assessed sensorimotor control (saccadic and pursuit eye movements), not social-related processing. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

This is an fMRI study using a validated pain-empathy paradigm that probes social processing (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes 21 healthy control participants alongside schizophrenia patients, satisfying the requirement for a healthy adult group. Not a review or meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study measuring brain responses of healthy adult football supporters during viewing of matches to investigate group bias and social interpretation processes. It involves a social-related task (group affiliation/bias) and healthy participants, meeting I1 and I2. Not a review or meta-analysis.

The study uses structural MRI and resting-state fMRI in a cohort of individuals with autism, not task-based social processing fMRI in healthy adults. Therefore it does not satisfy inclusion criteria I1 (task-based social fMRI) or I2 (healthy adult participants). Not a review article.

The study used resting-state fMRI (RSFC) rather than participants performing a social-related task, so inclusion criterion I1 is not met. It does include healthy controls (I2 met) and is not a review. Excluded based on failure to meet task-based fMRI inclusion.

Abstract reports an fMRI paradigm during theory-of-mind/social cognition tasks (meets I1) and explicitly includes a healthy control group (n=14) alongside patients and siblings (meets I2). No exclusion criteria apply. Age range not specified in abstract, but presence of healthy adult controls warrants inclusion for full-text review.
This article is a meta-analysis of 33 fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study; exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses) applies.

Abstract focuses on aggression in borderline personality disorder and does not state whether a healthy control group was included or whether the task is a social-related paradigm. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI social-cognitive task (neutral facial expression processing) in healthy adult participants characterized by schizotypy and genotype (n≈73–74). This meets the requirement of an fMRI during a social-related task and includes a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study used fMRI during a social interaction task (virtual handshake), satisfying I1. It includes a healthy control group, but ages (18–65) are not reported in the abstract; thus inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm I2.

fMRI study of social processing (direct vs averted gaze) during face perception; includes a matched control group of healthy adults alongside an ASC group. Meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (contains healthy adult participants). No exclusion criteria met.

The task used (Embedded Figures Task) is a visuospatial/perceptual task rather than a social-related task. Although the paper relates activation to social-communication severity in autism, the fMRI paradigm does not involve social processing as required by I1. Ages of participants are not specified, but exclusion is based on failure to meet I1. No systematic review/meta-analysis exclusion applies.

Abstract reports neural correlates during a dyadic social interaction, indicating an fMRI social task (I1). It examines psychopathic traits in participants, implying at least a group of adult participants likely healthy or with trait variation; age and health not explicit but insufficiently reported in abstract — include for full-text review (I2).

Participants are adolescents (13-year-olds), not adults aged 18–65, so the study fails inclusion criterion I2. The study does use fMRI during a social exclusion task (I1 met), but the age group excludes it from this review.

Abstract describes fMRI reward processing to monetary and object incentives in ASD and matched controls, not a social-related task or social processing (no affiliation, communication, or perception-of-others tasks). Thus it does not meet I1. Healthy controls are present but task is non-social, so exclude.

The fMRI task measured anticipation and fear of performing physical exercises (pain-related), not a social-processing task. Although the authors note engagement of ‘social cognition/mentalizing’ circuitry, the experiment does not target social interaction or perception/understanding of others. Healthy controls were included.

Resting-state fMRI study; no task-based social processing reported. Does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (must perform a social-related task during fMRI). It does include healthy controls, but that alone is insufficient.

Study used functional MRI while participants judged others' behaviors (social attribution/mentalizing), and included a healthy control group alongside BPD patients, meeting both fMRI social-task and healthy adult group criteria. Abstract provides sufficient information to determine inclusion.
Study used fMRI with the Cyberball social exclusion paradigm (a social-related task) and included a healthy control group of adult participants, satisfying both inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports three fMRI studies in which participants (American and Korean adults) performed persuasion tasks involving social-cognitive processing (mentalizing). This meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy participant groups). No exclusion criteria apply.

Sample consists of adolescents (developmental sample), not adults aged 18–65, so inclusion criterion I2 is not met. Additionally, the fMRI tasks assessed risk processing and cognitive control rather than social-related processing, so I1 is likely not met based on abstract. Exclude for population/task mismatch.

Abstract reports an fMRI attribution (social cognition) task including healthy control participants; however ages of participants (18–65) are not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The abstract explicitly states this is a review article (“In this review”), not an original fMRI study. It does not report functional MRI data collected from healthy adult participants, so it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract discusses fMRI studies of deception and relates to social cognition/theory of mind in human adults, but it reads like a narrative summary and does not clearly report original fMRI methods or participant details. Insufficient information to determine definitively from the abstract, so include for full-text review.

Resting-state fMRI in young children (mean age ~5 yrs) under sedation; not a task-based social processing fMRI and participants are children with ASD plus controls, not healthy adults aged 18–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

fMRI study examining face perception and social/emotional processing (attention to eyes vs mouth) — a social-related task. Includes 20 matched neurotypical young adult controls (healthy participants aged within adult range). Abstract clearly satisfies I1 and I2.

The abstract examines mirror neuron system function and altered brain activation during action imitation/observation (a social-related process), but does not explicitly state that an fMRI was used or that healthy adult controls were included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria from the abstract alone; include for full-text review.
The study reports fMRI during an interactive joint attention task (a social processing paradigm) and includes neurotypical adult groups (ages 18–65). Therefore it meets I1 and I2.

Abstract focuses on theory-of-mind neural networks in CHR youth but does not specify whether fMRI was used during a social task or whether a healthy adult (18–65) control group was included. Information is insufficient to determine eligibility from the abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating social reward (agreement with music experts) — a social-related task — and includes a matched stimulant-naive healthy control group. Fits inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI in healthy adults.

The study reports fMRI experiments on dynamic vs. static facial expressions, a social perception/communication task meeting I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state that participants were healthy adults, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI involving social-related processing, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. It does include healthy controls (I2), but absence of a social task excludes it from this review.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) in Williams syndrome patients and matched controls; it does not involve a social-related task as required by I1. Age of participants not specified as healthy adults 18–65. Not a systematic review. Therefore it fails the key inclusion criteria.
Study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing), and participants were adolescents rather than healthy adults aged 18–65. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

Primary data fMRI study (n=42) in healthy adult participants performing a social task involving understanding self and a romantic partner’s internal states (self/other processing). This addresses social-related processing (Perception/Understanding of Self and Others) and meets age/health group requirement. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract does not specify that fMRI was used, the task was social, or participant ages (18–65). Title implies atypical frontal activation in unaffected siblings, but insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to determine if I1 and I2 are met.

The study reports fMRI of human participants (mothers) viewing infant-related social/attachment stimuli, addressing affiliation/attachment processing. Participants are adult humans (presumably healthy mothers). Thus it meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (adult healthy participant group). No exclusion criteria apply.

Study used fMRI to measure neural responses to facial expressions (a social-related task) and reports a replication sample of healthy participants (North American healthy Caucasians). Age range not specified in abstract, so moderate confidence.

fMRI was used to measure brain activity during perception of others' actions (auditory and visual action recognition and motor pantomime), addressing perception/understanding of others (social processing). Participants include healthy congenitally blind and sighted adults. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.
Study reports fMRI in young children with autism only; no group of healthy adult participants (age 18–65) is described, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I2.

fMRI study using an explicit empathizing (social) task meets I1. The sample includes typically developing controls (TDC) aged 12–31; this likely includes adults within 18–31 meeting I2, but age-mixing introduces some uncertainty—full text needed to confirm adult-only data or extractable adult subgroup.

Abstract reports imaging of brain activation during emotion processing (a social-related task) in unaffected siblings, who are healthy adults; however the abstract doesn't explicitly state fMRI modality or participant ages. Insufficient detail to confirm modality/ages, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study using animated figures to probe animacy perception and mentalizing, clearly a social-cognitive task. Abstract reports neural activations in social brain regions; participants appear to be human adults with no disorders mentioned. Include for full-text to confirm ages if needed.

Study used resting-state fMRI to predict gender and did not involve a social-related task or social processing paradigm. Although participants were healthy adults (I2), the primary inclusion criterion I1 (task-based social processing) is not met. No exclusion criteria (e.g., E1) apply.

Abstract discusses parental brain and biobehavioral synchrony (a social process) but gives no methodological details (no mention of fMRI scanning, participant ages, or healthy adult sample). Insufficient information to confirm inclusion — include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adult fans (male college students) performing a task involving retrieval of emotionally valent memories from a social-group perspective (fan identity), addressing social cognition and social-affective processing. Abstract indicates social context and social-cognition relevance.
Abstract reports an fMRI facial emotion processing task (social-related processing) and includes 27 healthy control participants; thus meets I1 and I2. Age range not reported—confirm in full text.
The study is a quantitative meta-analysis of fMRI studies, which directly meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic reviews or meta-analyses). Excluded based on the abstract alone.

The study used disruptive transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), not functional MRI; therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (fMRI scan during a social-related task). The sample appears to be healthy adults (I2 satisfied) but absence of fMRI means exclusion.

The study reports two fMRI experiments probing perception of social actions (LOTC sensitivity to person presence, orientation, action directedness), matching the review objective of fMRI studies of social processing. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult groups, so full-text review is needed to confirm I2.

Human fMRI study of auditory emotion discrimination (social communication/perception of others). Task probes processing of others' affective vocal signals; abstract reports functional neuroimaging in human listeners (healthy participant sample implied). No exclusion criteria met.

Title and abstract indicate an imaging study of amygdala responses to emotional faces (a social-related task), but the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI nor whether healthy control participants were included. Insufficient detail to confirm all criteria—include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsfMRI) and EEG (MMN); no functional MRI during a social-related task was reported. Therefore inclusion criterion I1 (task-based fMRI during a social task) is not met. Healthy controls are present but this does not compensate for lack of task fMRI.

fMRI was conducted during a social task (multiround trust game) assessing responses to benevolence/malevolence (meets I1). The study includes a healthy comparison group of adult women (meets I2). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study used EEG (electrophysiology), not functional MRI, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (fMRI scan during task). Abstract reports healthy volunteers but modality mismatch is clear from abstract.

The study uses resting-state fMRI connectivity rather than an fMRI task involving social-related processing, so it does not meet I1. It does include a healthy control group (I2 satisfied) but absence of a social task precludes inclusion in this review.

fMRI BOLD responses were measured while healthy participants watched film scenes that evoke emotional conflicts involving social-cognitive processes (STS/IPL involvement), so the task addresses social-related processing. The abstract states healthy participants but does not report ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

Abstract reports an fMRI imaging study of emotional face processing (a social-related task), meeting I1. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

fMRI study used an implicit facial emotion (fear vs neutral) task assessing social processing (emotion/perception of others) and included a healthy control group (24 matched controls). No exclusion criteria apply.

Study used fMRI while participants performed a facial emotion perception task (a social cognition task). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=22) alongside an MDD group, meeting both inclusion criteria. Abstract provides sufficient information to determine inclusion.

Event-related fMRI during gesture planning and execution (a social communication/action task) and inclusion of a healthy control group (25 adults) meet the review criteria. Abstract clearly reports fMRI task and healthy participants.

The study used fMRI during a cognitive empathy task (social processing) and included a healthy control group (24 controls). Therefore it meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult participants present). No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study involving a social-related task (contemplation of parents, relevant to affiliation/attachment and social processing) and includes a healthy adult control group; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.
The study used positron emission tomography (PET), not functional MRI; therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (fMRI during a social-related task).

fMRI was used during a social-evaluation task (receiving negative vs positive social feedback), and the sample consists of 21 healthy adult men. The study directly examines neural responses to social processing, meeting both inclusion criteria.

The study reports an fMRI experiment during an interactive social task (Prisoner’s Dilemma), directly addressing social processing (I1). Participants are human males and females in a healthy sample implied by the context of intranasal OT/AVP treatment and comparison across sexes; no clinical population is described, satisfying I2 or, if uncertain, warranting full-text review. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing) and participants are individuals with autism rather than a healthy adult (18–65) group. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2; it is not a systematic review.

Abstract reports hyperscanning fMRI during real-time joint attention, a social processing task, satisfying I1. Participant health status and age range are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion regarding I2 cannot be confirmed; therefore include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining neural responses to others' eye gaze (social attention/perception) in typically developing adults. The task is social-related (perception of others), and participants are healthy adults, satisfying I1 and I2. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review and data extraction.

fMRI study where healthy subjects classified emotional gait—this is a social-related task addressing perception/understanding of others. Participants underwent fMRI; no indication of patient groups. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

This article is a narrative review summarizing ERPs and fMRI findings rather than reporting original fMRI data collected during a social task in healthy adults; thus it is not a primary fMRI study and should be excluded.

This study is a meta-analysis of fMRI findings in schizophrenia (a systematic meta-analysis), which meets exclusion criterion E1. Although it addresses social cognition (theory of mind), it is not an original fMRI study of healthy participants.

Abstract describes resting-state fMRI and task-related coactivation parcellation and notes involvement of social cognition, but does not state that participants performed a social-related task during fMRI or provide participant age/health details. I1 and I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI was used while participants performed supraliminal fearful face processing (a social/emotional perception task). Study includes a healthy control group of adults (controls matched on age and IQ), satisfying the age 18–65 requirement. Not a review or meta-analysis.

This study used magnetoencephalography (MEG), not functional MRI; thus it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 requiring fMRI during a social-related task. Participants are healthy adults, but absence of fMRI makes it ineligible for the review.

Study tested adolescents (with autism and siblings) using the Eyes task in fMRI; although I1 is met (social fMRI task), the sample consists of adolescents rather than healthy adults aged 18–65, so it does not satisfy I2 (no healthy adult group).

fMRI study of social processing (fearful face perception) with a healthy control group of adults; meets I1 (task-based fMRI of social-related processing) and I2 (at least one group of healthy adults). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study is itself a systematic review and meta-analysis of placebo-controlled imaging studies rather than a primary fMRI study of healthy adults performing social tasks, meeting exclusion criterion E1.

Abstract does not report a task-based fMRI study of social processing in humans. It uses resting-state connectivity, meta-analytic connectivity modeling, structural covariance and BrainMap meta-data to characterize the left anterior insula, but no social-related task was administered; therefore it fails inclusion criterion I1.

Abstract describes fMRI functional connectivity in autism spectrum disorder patients focusing on sensory-to-cognitive integration; it does not report a social-related task nor a healthy adult (18–65) sample. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

fMRI study where participants experienced an out-of-body vs in-body illusion during a social interaction, addressing perception/understanding of the self (a social-related construct). The abstract implies healthy human participants; includes at least one healthy group. Include for full-text to confirm ages/participant details.

Study samples adolescents/pediatric participants (social anxiety in adolescents). Although it uses fMRI with a social-evaluation task (I1), there is no healthy adult (age 18–65) group reported, so it fails the required adult healthy participant criterion (I2).

Abstract describes oxytocin effects on socially relevant cues in humans but gives no methods or participant details (no explicit mention of fMRI, task, or healthy adults). Insufficient information to confirm I1/I2 from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

The study examines cognitive emotion regulation to positive/negative pictures and amygdala/prefrontal activity, but does not investigate social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception of self/others). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I1. No exclusion criteria (E1) apply.

fMRI study of social-related processing (self- and other-referential perspective-taking) that includes a typically developed healthy adult control group; meets criteria for task-based fMRI of social constructs and presence of healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI in adolescents (early-onset schizophrenia) rather than task-based social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet I1 (no social task) nor I2 (healthy participants aged 18–65). No exclusion criteria (e.g., reviews) apply.

Abstract is truncated and does not specify whether a task-based fMRI was used or whether any healthy adult participants (age 18–65) were included. Title suggests social cognition and DMN connectivity in co-occurring ASD and ADHD, and it is not a review article. Include for full-text review to determine I1 and I2.

Resting-state fMRI used a social manipulation (standardized critical remarks) to probe processing of criticism/social evaluation. Participants appear to be healthy adults. This meets I1 (social-related processing during fMRI) and I2 (healthy adult sample).

The study samples children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorder and does not report a healthy adult (age 18–65) participant group. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I2 (healthy adults 18–65).

Abstract describes relating SRS-A scores to intrinsic functional connectivity in neurotypical adults but does not report an fMRI task assessing social processing. This likely reflects resting-state/connectivity analysis rather than task-based social processing, so it fails inclusion criterion I1.

Abstract describes neural correlates of facial emotion processing (a social-related task), indicating relevance to social processing (I1). The abstract does not clearly state use of fMRI or whether a healthy control group was included (I2). Insufficient details to confirm methods/participants; include for full-text review to verify.

The study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 (no social-related task). Healthy controls are present but I1 is not satisfied.

This paper is a review and meta-analysis rather than an original fMRI study; it meets exclusion criterion E1. The abstract does not present primary fMRI data in healthy adults, so it should be excluded based on the study type.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing), so it does not meet I1 (functional MRI during a social-related task). Healthy controls are present but the key social-task criterion is not satisfied. Not a systematic review.

Study used event-related fMRI to measure neural responses to infant cries and faces (social/attachment-related stimuli) in nulliparous adult women, meeting the social-related task and healthy adult participant criteria. Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI was conducted in a non-clinical (healthy) cohort using the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, a social cognition task, satisfying I1. The abstract does not report participant ages (18–65), so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify age criteria and details.

Abstract reports an fMRI investigation of self-referential processing and perspective-taking (social cognition constructs), satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify whether a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) was included, so inclusion for full-text review is needed to determine I2.

Abstract reports fMRI during a theory-of-mind (social cognition) task in healthy volunteers (n=109). This directly meets the review objective and inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports fMRI connectivity analysis of emotional processing (a social-related construct: perception/understanding of others' emotions), but does not specify whether a healthy adult control group was included. Insufficient information to determine participant groups; include for full-text review to confirm presence/age range of healthy participants and task details.

This study used resting-state fMRI/DSI to examine visuospatial working memory in adolescents with ASD and TD controls; it did not involve a task-based social-processing fMRI in healthy adults. Does not meet I1 or I2.

Study examines face-processing (social cognition) in community young adults with functional and structural MRI data; participants are healthy adults within 18–65. Abstract does not specify whether the BOLD data were acquired during a social task (task vs. resting-state is unclear), so inclusion criterion I1 cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to clarify task-based fMRI.

Study uses an fMRI visuomotor precision-grip (sensorimotor) task in individuals with ASD, not a social-related task in healthy adults. Abstract does not report healthy adult social-processing fMRI, so it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task) to assess oxytocin effects on connectivity; the review requires fMRI during a social-related task (I1). Abstract clearly indicates no task-based social processing, so exclude.

Resting-state fMRI in youth aged 8–15; not a task-based social processing study and does not include healthy adult participants (18–65). Thus it fails inclusion criteria I1 and I2. No exclusion criteria (e.g., reviews) apply.

The study used resting-state fMRI in adolescents with autism (ABIDE); it did not involve a social-related task and participants are adolescents with ASD rather than healthy adults aged 18–65, so it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

Participants are described as 'boys', indicating a child/adolescent sample rather than healthy adults aged 18–65 required by I2. Although an fMRI social-context encoding task was used (I1 met), the control group are not within the target adult age range, so the study does not meet inclusion criterion I2.

The abstract describes a review summarizing and evaluating 103 brain-imaging studies (a literature review/systematic review), so it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses (E1). The abstract does not present a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract examines frontal control over social approach-avoidance actions and HPA-axis reactivity, relevant to social processing. However, it does not explicitly state that a functional MRI scan was used or confirm participant ages/health status. Insufficient information in abstract to determine I1/I2, so include for full-text review to confirm fMRI use and healthy adult sample.

This study reports resting-state fMRI in youth with autism (clinical sample), not a task-based social-processing fMRI in healthy adults. It therefore does not meet inclusion criteria I1 (social task fMRI) or I2 (healthy adults 18–65).

Abstract focuses on social interactive deficits in BPD but does not specify that a functional MRI task was used nor whether healthy adult controls (ages 18–65) were included. Insufficient information to confirm I1 or I2, so include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a social cognition task (modified Sally-Anne) and includes a typically developing control group (17 males), meeting I1 and likely I2. Ages 18–65 are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.
Study reports resting-state fMRI in autism spectrum disorder, not an fMRI task of social processing in healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet I1 (task-based social fMRI).
